content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												Tokyo Drift? Initial D? VDrift? If anything of this appeals to you, this might too.In any case, this game's remarkable. It's challenging, exciting and unforgiving. But let me tell you, it's just as satisfying once you get a feel for it.You start out in a minimalistic world, sitting in the infamous Toyota Trueno AE86. Your destiny? Drift. A brief tutorial follows, which will probably result in you crashing into walls a lot, but that's fine, as nothing else really is needed to understand how this game works! The game then releases you into a free-roaming environment with a few missions you have to do to unlock more stages. You can then also select stages, cars and tracks once in Free-roam mode, a bit like in NFS or other racing titles.As you get more familiar with the controls, the stages get more exciting and challenging/longer. They also come in several formats: Lap-based drift-tracks, Driftkhana, which is a highscore time-attack inside an arena, or mountain sprint tracks. The goal is always the same, drift gracefully, score points, interact with objects such as poles to drift past or boxes to shatter, add that up to the final score and remain away from hitting walls or losing your combo. Sounds easier than it is, trust me, the Japanese themed tracks and names will kick into your curb at first.That said, car handling is the key, each car has their own way of handling, so finding what suits you most will be the way to go. Ontop of that, drifting's the deal, so going fast won't always be the key to success either. Manual or automatic shifting? How high should be the turning sensitivity? Well, all these factors will help you optimize your driving style, making it possible to reach up to be the drift king.I personally had, and will have a blast with this title in the future. It's been a while since I found an appealing drifting/racing experience and I can safely say this game has done it right. Now go... Go... and be the next Drift-King.

Posted: August 6, 2016
It's spinning drifting time! Pros:+ 6 different cars to drive+ Has achievements and trading cards+ Controller support, with smooth controls+ Fitting soundtracks to add to your "Leet driving skillz" + 3 game modes to play for leaderboard lovers with 24+ levels+ Free roam is interesting and fun, featuring themed levels, range of missions and good level designNeutral Points:> No multiplayer, which is a shame because I feel it would be fun> Difficulty, getting used to the drifting is not easy, can be frustrating when trying to get that high scoreCons:- Price tag is too high for what the game offers- Game is short, offering roughly 3 hours of content- No replayability, boring after you've completed it all- Controls are sensitive, spinning out or losing control is commonRandom totally (not) true notes: None of the cars have cup holders, blue shells from mario kart have a slight chance to appear from another dimension and mess you up, and drifting doesn't mean drift to sleep (I learned that the hard way and spilt my coffee)Download Size: 421mbTrading cards: 6 cards in the setAchievement Difficulty: Moderately difficultHours to 100%: 3+Rating: 7.5/10Recommendation: Grab it on a big sale for a couple hours of driving, sliding, crashing and attempted drifting. I'd recommend a controller too. Not worth the full price howeverMy opinion:Interesting and entertaining, it does what it sets out to do well. It is ok for one playthrough but is boring after, plenty to do if you like getting your name on the leaderboards but the drifting takes a good while and some practice to get good with. Difficult without practice but once you got the drifting down getting all the achievements are easy. Levels are nicely designed and the free roam is fun to play, the 3 other modes are somewhat fun but more for the competitive types trying to get the highest scores/times. For the full price tag of £8.99 it's not worth it in my opinion, best get it heavily discounted. I feel it would of been nice to have some multiplayer, maybe then it would be worth the price.

All three modes in the game, Drift, Driftkhana, and Free-Roam teach you the skills required for drifting in addition to providing dozens of hours of replayability for those attempting to get the best scores possible. The game is incredibly challenging, and posting top scores to the leaderboards for the event mode levels will be reserved for only the best of the best as the skill ceiling for the game is incredible high.

Posted: July 30, 2015
												Let me try to describe how I feel about this game. In fact, let me swoon over it, let me drool all over my keyboard. This game feels absolutely perfect. Surely it is not a perfect game as there should/could be still some content added like maybe a simple map designing tool (with workshop support?). This game actually looks very simple, the surface is white and each of your tyres leaves skidmarks to see how smoothly each of your four wheels cleared a corner. Important things are coloured red. I am not cutting to the chase, but the feeling of "Absolute Drift" is just great. this game lets you peacefully control a car sliding around a menu-like open map with objectives to do and areas to unlock. There are special tracks for each gamemode which can be entered. The atmosphere is well-rounded with an electronic soundtrack, subtle tyre squealing and rich car sounds.I like to drive the car of my family in real life and I got experience with racing games like "Live For Speed", "SHIFT 2 Unleashed" or "BeamNG.drive". So before I tried this game I already had some drifting experience (using a steering wheel), which most likely helped me get into this game quickly.If you are not sure, whether you like the game mechanics, you can check for a demo on indieDB, though it is by far not as developed as the final game.So should you buy this game and support the developers? Definitely, yes!Well, given that you are into going sideways, but if you are looking at this, you probably are.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												Absolute Drift is a *gasp* drifting game. Of course the most important part of a vehicle game of any sort are the controls. I will admit that the controls in Absolute Drift are quite tight while the driving itself does feel a bit too slippery, but as you might guess it’s not a big deal in a game where your only goal is to slide stylishly. Absolute Drift also boasts a unique Japanified minimalist aesthetic, paying homage to one of the origins of the drifting motorsport. It isn’t all roses but let’s not hesitate to pop the hood and see what we got, this is Absolute Drift.Free Roam mode serves as the Story Mode, and will serve to introduce you to the controls as well as different challenges and events. After spinning out a few times and learning the art of counter-steering you will begin to grasp what the game is really all about and because there is very little hand-holding, conquering a world challenge or topping the global highscore for any track feels like a great accomplishment. Absolute Drift has a total of 23 tracks to enjoy; 10 circuit Drift tracks, 9 open-world Driftkhana courses, and 4 one-way Mountain Drift tracks, so you can find the event that suits you best.While the world challenges and events have as much variety as can be expected, I find that it still isn’t quite enough. Drift around this, drift between that, it isn’t until the last stage that things start getting really interesting. All I’m saying is I wanted to jump on a few more roofs. Car customization is limited to 6 body-types, which all have a slightly different feel. You can also pick a color and a decal, but nothing beyond that. I would really like a chance to fine-tune my engine and shocks. Stripped-down customization and lack of real-time damage are gigantic missed opportunities.I enjoyed my time with Absolute Drift, with its low-key dance music soundtrack, inoffensive looks, and high degree of mastery. Lack of customization and content hurts replayability, but the difficulty curve and global scoreboards means it still has quite a bit to offer. The story mode can be completed in around 2 hours, and if that’s all you’re buying this game for then $12 might be a bit overpriced. It is a bit of a one-trick pony, but it does that trick extremely well. If you’re in the mood for a score-attack drifting game, give Absolute Drift a try. Though it might be worth waiting for a sale. Big thanks to Funselektor Labs for the review copy! We at IGB hope to see more quite soon.Gameplay:    Controls- 8/10    Fun Factor- 4/10    Difficulty- 3/10    Replayability- 8/10    Innovation- 7/10Aesthetic:    Graphics- 7/10    Music- 9/10    Sound FX- 6/10    Story/Lore- 1/10    Level Design- 6/10Final Score: 59/100 for replayability, controls, and music.Summary: Minimalist drifting simulator with a large degree of difficulty, and a rocking soundtrack.Verdict: A bit of a one-trick pony, but it does that trick exceedingly well. Catch it on sale.Full text/photo review: http://www.indiegamebundles.com/review-absolute-drift/Full "Lets Review" video:

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
So, here it is. My review.At time of posting, I have all the achievements and have 50 hours in the game.First of all, just a general comment: I love this game. It has a great, smooth game engine and the controls are fairly easy to me. It wasn't too hard to pick up, and learning some drifiting from Assetto Corsa and driving my Miata IRL, I can say that the physics are very realistic and it's easy to apply those skills into this game.Here's a list for the TL:DR, and it's at the top (you're welcome):Pros:- Smooth Game Engine- Difficulty Settings are Spot On- Controls on Every Difficultly Setting are Great- Music is Great (Especially C41; sorry Nyte, your music is still great, lol)- Colors are Great- Online Leaderboards- Fairly wide selection of Maps- Driftkhana, Drift Tracks, and Mtn Drift settings are awesome to choose from- Game is Updated at a Good Pace- Game as a Whole was Tailored for a Wide audience- Wide Range of Adjustable Graphics Settings to Fit your Performance Needs- Different cars fit different people, but aren't too unbalanced in terms of full capabilites.- Free-Roam. Yesssssss...- Less than 500 MB (currently)- Very Fair and Rewarding Point system that pushes you to try harderCons:- Non-customizable Controls (Steam Controller's Reprogramming Defeats this Con)- No-multiplayer, yet (for reasons)Otherwise, this game is perfect in my opinion.Okay, now the novel:Personal CommentsI have owned this game since August 2015 and have really been off and on with it. I can tell you that once I got a Steam Controller, everything changed, and I loved how the game played with it. Honestly, I couldn't play it on anything but the highest difficulty. PhysicsThe physics are phenomenal. I don't think I have ever played such an arcad-ey styled game with such realistic physics. It totally replicates real life (or damn near it) and the developer did such a great job with it. From what I have seen, there are no current bugs in the game's physics and I see no reason for the physics to be modified at all.GraphicsThe graphics are great aswell. I think that the color theme is perfect for the (not so much) "JDM/Dorifto" and (but more) Japan feel. It is a little brutal on the eyes when you're in a dark room or are very tired, but otherwise, it is very fun and keeps you alert. I really enjoy how the tire marks work. They really help when you are drifitng if you need to see if you're angle is going too far (genenrally more than 90º), and they look cool. The graphics, in general, may seem a little bland at times, but it really keeps you focused on what you're doing. Plus, this game isn't really about looks, it's more about the gameplay.Gameplay/ControlsAny kind of controller (I use a Steam Controller) is nearly a must. Keyboard is simply not enough to fully enjoy and get good at this game, but it is still playable. It really sucks that you can't change the controls in game, but the Steam Remapping or something like motioninjoy could help with that. The actual controlling on all difficulties is great and accurate to their names. The hardest difficulty feels butter smooth and is what I use all the time. If you take your time, you can really learn the game and get good with a car that fits you. I personally work well with "The Original," but who knows what you might be great with. Also, there is always a mixture of challenging yourself, the music, and the map you're on that can give you different moods within the game.This game is also very fun and easy to get back into and keep with. I think that in general, it may get boring after you completely master (rank 1) all of the maps and finish the campaign, but it would take a long time (probably no less than 150 hours) before you get to that point. At least for me, the game pushes me to try harder and be the best at any map I try. I am currently, as of this review, number 4 on Mt. Nikko with about 300,000 points to go to number 1. It's taken me about 15 hours to get to that point and I don't plan on stopping until I am at number 1.Last WordsThis game is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. I don't even think curse words can explain how awesome this game is. I think that the game has come a very long way in the past 9 months and I think that it has amazing potential. funselektorlabs deserves a lot of credit for the creation of this game. I can't wait to see how this game evolves because it would be a shame if it were to stop where it is. However, it wouldn't be horrible because the game is already amazing as-is.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Points SystemThe point system is very fair and I think I have it figured out, in general. Here's my thoughts:- Depending on drifting direction, a sideways-sliding score is given, and it's when the most rear wheel in a drift (if you're going right, it's the rear right) is farther out than the forward wheel (if you're drifting around a right corner, it's your left front, and vice-versa):- This is the general "drifitng score."- The wider the angle up to a 90º drift is more points- You get a multiplier based upon how long you have been drifing "continuously"- If you're going too slow, the points stop adding- If you go over 90º, the points stop adding- If you hit anything, except bonuses, your points are summed in the total and you lose your multiplier- If you stop drifing for too long (I think about 5 seconds), your points are summed in the total and you lose your multiplier- Extra points are given when you go around a bonus pole:- The closer you are, the more points you get- The faster you are going, the more points you get- If you're too far away or "aren't drifitng" near one, it doesn't count- If you hit one, it doesn't count, but doesn't get rid of your score or multiplier- Extra points are given when you hit a red block:- If you hit it you get points- If you don't hit it, you get no points- Faster and more Sideways you are, you get more points- Extra points are given when you go around a donut circle (driftkhana only):- If you finish the donut indicated with the increasing red circle, you get more points- Faster and more Sideways you are, you get more points- If you hit it, you get no points- Extra points are given when you spin in a "spin-zone" (driftkhana only):- If you finish the spinning indicated with the increasing red circle, you get more points- There's really no downside to these...- Points are inceased exponentially (I don't know how much the curve is) if you stack bonuses in one "continuous" drift:- If you keep getting bonuses, they'll exponentially increase- If your current score is reset, so does your bonus stack

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												Absolute Drift is one of the best drifting and car related games ever made. If not THE best.  The game is incredibly simple at face value, which lends to the game being both aesthetically and mechanically perfect. Its top down perspective and simple visuals work fantastic together. You get a broad view of your canvas, allowing you to cut amazing drifts and prepare where to go to create the best line. The cars to choose from (including a BMW, an AE-86, a Supra, all made as generic cars with nods to their real life counterparts) are incredible. Again- all this is due to its simplicity, and the simplicity was very goal driven by design. When you look at your car- it gives the same feelings you had with your Hotwheels as a kid, they all control as people expect them to (The AE-86 is so well balanced it's essentially all I use, just like the the real life Toyota is percieved to be) .... They perform as your tool to navigate the perfect drift, and at the same time they are the tip of your paint brush that is marking the canvas laid out before you- painting the world in black ink as you weave and arc your way around- the sound of your rev pinging and tires squeeling as you yank the E-Brake and swing back the other way is spot on. //Drifting as an art.That's the beauty of this game. It gets Drift culture better than any other video game before it. It doesn't slap you in the face with popular culture, icons, brands... It bleeds the emotion and style of Drifting, and that's it. The only real world reference beyond the cars themselves, are the Torii that dot the landscape, which are the gateways to the next chapter in free-roam... And the japanese chimes that play as you make your way to the next level. (Remember their use in this? 


YouTube™ Video: Tokyo Drift - Teriyaki Boyz [ MUSIC VIDEO ] HD 

			Views: 37,276,169		

			Fast and Furious Tokyo Drift - Teriyaki Boyz		

 ...Fantastic)  The Japanese imagery and use of a paint-brush on canvas visual style bleeds Drifting as an art form. A pure form of expression through controlling a car. It's respectful to the art, but mechanically this is incredible as well. //Pitch perfect Drifting mechanicsThe game will start you off and tell you how to drift- it puts you through a simple tutorial before letting you loose on this clean playground- a playground with real world objects... Ferris wheels that make me think of the pier in LA, train yards and other construction type objects that help me to imagine drifting in big open back lots late at night. It's all so clean and perfect that  much like reading a book, it allows you to fill in the blanks with your own perception of the craft. Just the way it should be. But again, the craft itself is just as important- and the tutorial gets you on the path and then drops you in to learn the rest yourself. The other major part of pure drift-culture is failure and success. Learning your car, learning physical limitations, tinkering with your setup (in this case the controls to match your comfort, turn sensitivity and "difficulty" which to me is more of a way that the car acts- try medium and hard as well, as you may find the car acts a bit more like it should in your mind) ... Failing and trying again until you learn how to drift and master a course. That's the thing about drifting and people who actually do it. It's a comradery thing- it's something you don't learn over night, it's not all about showing off and looking "hella dope" ... It's about mastering something with a deep learning curve and perfecting it. It's about risk and reward. For a top-down arcade style racer, this game allows you to do just that, while still BEING A VIDEO GAME and not a NASA-sponsored sim of the craft itself. I can't say this enough, aesthetically and mechanically this game NAILS the art and culture of drifting better than any game before it, and likely after it too.//Presentation is everythingAnd present it does. It is effortless here. No obnoxious menus to slog through. You can go back to the main menu from a course in free-roam nearly instantly, and the music doesn't change either. That's a BIG thing too. The music is perfect ambient EDM tracks. All majorly chill. They all fit and hit the modern car-culture perfectly and enhance your driving experience while doing it. The first track to start when I loaded up the game the first time was perfect- with an awesomely simple title splash that slides perfectly into the game as you hit Enter... The game feels perfectly put together. Every piece fits seamlessly... And as I swap to a different mode or back out and the music doesn't suddenly cut or change- that helps to make the package feel that much more "whole" and perfect.Simplicity here is key. The game doesn't use simplicity to hide faults it possibly could have if they added more- it uses it so that you notice and gravitate to the things you SHOULD while playing it. The mechanics and ink-brush style of your drift. It's zen. Absolute Drift is Zen. Fun to play for a couple minutes while waiting for your friends to get grouped for a dungeon in WoW or Competitive CS GO. Fun to play with your coffee while you wake up. Fun to just play for hours with no interest in doing anything else- just to top the leaderboards or channel your inner DK. Absolute Drift is just that- Absolute Drift.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
												I've had tears of joy playing this game to completion, which is a rarity, I will say.Absolute Drift is a top down, minimalistic stunt driving game. Your goal: become a master drifter, by refining the art of spinning out and smashing into walls controlling oversteer and burning rubber.For the aesthetics: it's low poly, simple graphics, with most buildings and roads left white and untextured. Objects of interest are coloured red, blue or yellow. Your car leaves behind skidmarks wherever it goes, whether you slide or not, which allows for impressive drawings on tarmac, or a nice spiral when you catch some big air.The soundtrack is a relaxing, upbeat electronic and DnB by Nyte and C41 respectively - which fits the near zen-like atmosphere of the game. Cars have simple, but distinct engine noises, with more subtle transmission whine or turbo flutter.The gameplay is the purest I've seen in modern driving games. It's you, your car, your skills and the track. Whether free-roaming, doing driftkhanas or mountain drifts, almost everything revolves around getting your back end slideways and very, very smokey. You have a selection of 6 cars to choose from, each performing differently from one another - some are heavier, some are more stable, some are more tail happy. All can be repainted and given a little livery. You'll spend most of your time smacking against walls drifting in an open-ended hub world, peppered with missions to perform - stuff like "drift between this and this" or "donut around this". Finishing the campaign takes around 1.5 hours, but you also have specific tracks - the aforementioned driftkhanas, mountain drifts and circuit drifts, containing Steam leaderboards that will push you to improve your scores.Let's not beat around the bush; the game is hard. The handling is intentionally challenging. Unless you're careful, it doesn't matter whether you use the gamepad or the keyboard, you WILL spin out and hit walls, and the game knows it. There are several difficulty settings to pick from, which change how grippy your car is, but above all, mastery of counter-steer, weight transfer, grip limit, torque and gearing is paramount to any decent drifting in this world. This results in one of the most satisfying moments I've ever experienced in videogames: the flow of stringing together perfect drifts through a tight and twisty track, losing as little momentum as possible and rocketing to the top. The execution of the handling is absolutely STELLAR.The game has finally been upgraded to the Zen Edition, bringing forth a new event type - Midnight Drifts, which are really really challenging! In addition, you have Event Challenges to unlock said Midnight Drifts, REPLAYS and GHOSTS on the tracks! This is the kind of free content that will exponentially boost the game's longevity, even if a level editor or proper multiplayer still don't quite exist yet. I'd liken this game as the Portal of driving games: a clean art style, a short campaign that doesn't overstay its welcome, if it's not over too quick, a dash of humour and one of the best (top down, minimalistic, very very slideways) driving experiences I've had in my long years of driving/racing games. I f-ing love it!Get it ASAP if you like/love cars, but even if you don't it's worth a try for the experience and the challenging but rewarding gameplay.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
"Absolute Drift" Review *Disclaimer: This game was purchased for personal use, not provided by a developer. Absolute Drift, herein abbreviated as AD, is essentially a minimalistic casual driving game. You play from a 3D, third person “top-down” perspective, as you traverse 7 worlds completing various drifting tasks. The goal? Become a master drifter, sliding over water and doing donuts around Ferris Wheels. Here are a few things worth noting. Art Style The elegant contrast of white landscapes against bright red obstacles is the key idea behind the art style of AD. The graphics look gorgeous with their minimalistic textures and subtle physics. As you drive through stacks of blocks, you’ll be blown away at how the particles just seem to fall away without hesitation. The soundtrack is perfectly suited for the game, and huge props to the artists for their great work in that department. Difficulty The game seems simple at first – get your car sideways, countersteer, and you’re set. It’s not quite that easy. In free roam you will learn how to stay in drifts and exit the drift whenever you need to. Meanwhile, you can use various events to hone your skills on-track. There’s no difficulty toggle here – in events you are ranked against other players in global and friend-based rankings. Length, Story, Etc. One of the only gripes I had with this game was the length of the free roam world. There are seven “worlds” you go through before having to resort to replaying tracks over and over just to beat your own times. I would love to see a co-op or even online 1-on-1 game mode in this, and it would definitely give it a bit more reason to play beyond free-roam. Performance AD runs phenomenally on my rig, as I expected. However, as with all my reviews, I tested the game on Intel Integrated Graphics to see how well it would do for casual gamers. It ran at a solid 35 or so fps, definitely within a playable range. You could likely push it to 50 by playing 1280x720 windowed.Do I like this game? Absolutely. (Pardon the pun) I would recommend it to anyone looking for a game that they can complete with 100% achievements in less than 5 hours. If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator GroupCurator text: Absolute Drift is a masterpiece with its elegant graphics and fantastic physics. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 12 of 12 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												I didn't know anything about Absolute Drift before buying it, but I knew I liked racing, drifting and that this game had a large portion of positive reviews. So I thought, "why not?". Here's what I think of this game after a few hours of play:Graphics: I've always been a huge fan of minimalist/subtle designs, and Absolute Drift pretty much nails that. Everything has a low polygon count. The track is white, the important things are red and the death zone (water) is blue. This very small color palette is great because you can very quickly understand any situation you are in, but it also carries a message that, I think, translates the game well: "No BS, just drifting".The black skidmarks felt kind of strange at first because they are here even when not drifting, but then I understood they were here to serve as a visualization of your driving, because they contrast the pure white track. By simply looking at the skidmarks, you can judge how well your took that last corner. More simply, it just looks nice.On a more technical aspect, at the time I am writing this, the game is very poor. The graphical options are very limited: no custom resolutions, no V-Sync and the graphical quality is limited to a few presets, which means you can't set the anti-aliasing, texture filtering, etc. on your own. Then again, the game launched very recently, so I have faith the developer will add those options later.Audio: The cars sound good, you can really feel how powerful they are when accelerating and the hissing sound of the tires when drifting is satisfying. The soundtrack blends in very well with the game. It's all electro music (like Drum & Bass), but all of the tracks are very calm. It was a good choice to make the soundtrack relaxing because the player will spend a lot of time failing and retrying, but the tranqulity of those tunes help remain calm.Gameplay: Here comes the most important part, and fortunately, it's the best. The control scheme is pretty much what you'd expect in any driving game: Left-Right-Accelerate-Brake-Handrake-Gear up-Gear down. Learning how the game works takes two minutes at worst, but knowing how to handle the cars themselves is a harder task. You cannot make a normal turn in this game, you will always slide. On top of that, the cars feel very heavy: even when you think you're going pretty slow, drifting will barely make you deccelerate and you will very often end up in a wall because of that at the beginning. When you get the hang of this, however, driving becomes a very smooth experience. You can easily chain multiple drifts and properly gauge acceleration/decceleration.The developper made the very interesting decision of only giving the player an isometric point of view instead of the good old 1st/3rd person cameras you can find in other racing games. It's quite useful because it allows the player to see further ahead than they normally could, and plan their drifts in consequence.Content: The game is split in two modes: Free-roam, where you drive in open spaces completing missions (which usually are "drift near this", "donut around that", etc.) to open new worlds where you complete more missions, and Events where you can choose to play on either Tracks (with 3 laps), Driftkhanas (small, open spaces where you must score as many points as possible in 2 minutes) and Mountain Drifts (tracks where you drift downhill to the end). There is, at the time of writing, 5 worlds and 24 tracks. The 5 worlds can be completed in about an hour or two and each world also unlocks various Events and one car.Something unfortunate is that all cars are, unless I have not played enough to realize the difference, model+sound swaps. It would have been nice to give all cars a different handling, but perhaps the dev will add this in the future.The good thing about Events is their replayability and the presence of a Leaderboards system. If you want to climb that ladder you will have to master every corner of every track, which is not an issue given how good the cars feel. The large amount of hours sinkable justifies, I believe, the price tag.One thing I would really love to see is the addition of a map maker (perhaps with Workshop integration) in order to enhance the lifespan of this game.In conclusion, I would definitely recommend this little gem if you are the kind of person who likes spending a large amount of time on a single game in order to master it.

												I bought this game while it was on sale.  Me and my friend beat the game 100%.  It was mostly my friend though.Its a good game.  The game's sole focus is drifting.  Its not about upgrades and such, its all about drifting.  Theres no enemy AI to race against or anything like that.  Pros:fun gameplaylooks good in its own wayvery satisfying game to be good atyou can drive manualeasy with controller (I didnt play it with mouse and keyboard so I cant say how good it is with that setup)Cons:-Engine sounds could be a little better.  They sound kinda like cartoon versions of real engines and they're always freaking redlining.  It gets old.  -Not a lot of customization available for cars-not a whole lot of cars (like 7)-No NPCs.  (good and bad. nobody to bother you but also nobody to race or drift with)-Challenges can be very difficult.-Automatic transmission is garbage.  Im not saying that because Im a manual douchelord. No, I tried it.  I gave it a chance and theres no way you can drift with it.  You have to play manual.  IF you dont know how to play manual this could be a big negative.Overall, I got my money's worth out of this game.  Even if I would have payed full price I would have been satisfied.  It's worth a buy.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												A simple concept beautifully exectued. Casual and relaxing but also competetive if you're in that mood. The minimalistic graphics and relaxing music creates a very likeable atmosphere (Mirror's Edge comes to mind). The controls are fluid and the physics surprisingly good, which makes the game challenging but also rewarding when you nail a run. There are some annoying bugs, but nothing major. The sound goes wonky sometimes but a restart of the event fixes it and for some reason the car is in reverse at the start of a race occasionally."Story mode" is very brief and contains tutorials for the different race modes and simple missions. Missions are repetitive (spin here, do donuts around that, drift through here) and you'll spend a lot of time driving around trying to find the last ones to unlock the next area. I wouldn't recommend this game for the price if you're just going to play through the free roam mode as the content just isn't there. But if you enjoy perfecting your skills there's a lot of replay value and leaderboards to climb. There are three modes: track, mountain pass and gymkhana and quite a few locations for each.Unfortunatley there seems like some cheating or exploiting exists as some high scores on certain tracks are outright impossible to achieve (I've seen scores ten times higher than second place) but unless you're able to score in the top 3 or so this won't affect you much.Still, overall a very enjoyable and well executed game. I hope to see more from the developer.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												Absolute Drift is butter on toast.. Smooth afDriving is similar to the early top down GTA games, in that the camera doesn't sit behind the car so steering becomes inverted at times. The cars themselves, handle as if fine tuned to float like sand bags on an ice rink.It's a little like the 'Skate' games in that you'll be finding areas of the free roam map and then sessioning that area, only instead of a curb or a rail it's a docking crane and a lamp post.The "5 Worlds" are pretty big, each with a couple dozen drifting challanges (tricks highlighted in red) that need to be completed for the bridge to the next zone to drop. Once all zones are connected they form a rather epic playground, diverse and beautifuly crafted. There is no loading between zones so free roam is exactly that.The "Events"  are Driftkhana, Drifting, & Mountain Drifting (foremost being a timed freestyle session, the others being un-timed single/3 lap trials respectively). All masterfully crafted, resonating a 'hitman GO' kind of ambience.There are another two dozen of these, and I found everyone of them enjoyable.The Events, were rather challanging while the free roam challanges known as "Missions", were far too forgiving. You could half complete a spin twice and it would register as succesfull, for example.The Soundtrack is exceptional and worth the price of admission alone. I'm not being facetious, growing up in an era where albums sold for £15/$25 I would have happily dropped a tenner on this score. The music is perfect, sliding through a ceramic China town to C41 - On my way, everything just comes together. Worth noting that while the game isn't in a pre release state the devs are still actively pushing out content and patches, the creator has said this game was a labor of love, and it shows.9/10Could use more content and maybe a way to save and share footage. But what is there is a masterpiece in top down drifting and game design.

number of helpful: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												Inspired by Ken Block’s Gymkhana series the best way to describe the game is the driving view point of micro machines, the score system of the trick sections in Project Gotham racing, the progression system of an N64 era platform game and a fantastic drift system that takes an age to master but always makes you feel it is your fault if you screw up.The game sees you progress through a number of worlds that act as the hub to complete missions. These range from performing stunts around obstacles to performing on tracks to gain points and get a world ranking.There are 3 types of events Driftkhana, Drifting, & Mountain Drifting but all are essentially a playground to gain as many points as possible. Controlled best with a gamepad the game takes about 5 minutes to understand, 10 minutes to become competent and even after several hours of game play I still did not feel I had truly mastered it.Visually the game is minimalistic but lovely to look at and run at a solid 60fps. The music soundtrack is also filled with tranquil base numbers.Now the game is not perfect. Relatively short I finished everything in a few hours and while trying to get higher up the league tables offers the game some replayability I feel that this will not be for everyone. I also felt that a more detailed tutorial to give tips on how to perfect drifting at the start as it took a lot of crashing into walls to really get the difference between how brake and handbrake acts.I enjoyed the game a lot and for the low price of £9.99 of your regional equivalent it is hard to not recommend but this isn’t a game which you will be playing for ages unless you really are a score attack gamer.Check out our video review here http://www.thegametutor.co.uk/videos/game-tutor-grades/150731_game-tutor-grades-absolute-drift

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												This is an excellent, laid back game about drifting through life with a chill soundtrack in the background and some really interesting physics-based gameplay in the foreground. Keep in mind that mastering control of your car through a drift is the primary gameplay loop here, so if you simply can't stand ice levels this is probably not the game for you. If you can get past that, though, there's a beautiful open-ish world (segmented off by challenges) with a wealth of things to drift around, through, in and over - as well as special levels that challenge you to drift through a course, or score as high as possible in an arena with a time limit. There's even a lighthouse named Donut! 


Why is the lighthouse named donut 
A Screenshot of Absolute Drift
By: Tacroy




At this point, the game's even taken its special anti-nausea edibles - so if you were put off by the camera in older Let's Plays (particularly during spins), give it another shot. One thing I would like to see is a bit more interactivity throughout the open world - sure, there's challenges you can accomplish and ramps you can jump off of and stacks of blocks you can knock down, but there's not much you can do to change the layout of the levels; it would be neat if you could (for instance) trigger a crane to raise a wall by doing a donut around a lever, or create a ramp by knocking over some of its supports. That sort of thing would be really cool, but it would just be an enhancement on an already great game.

												GOTY 2015, without a doubt in my mind.Absolute Drift is the best driving game on PC, period. If you're like me, poor and without a 180SX of you're own, fire up Absolute Drift and get sideways to an absolutely stellar soundtrack! Absolute has a really simplistic "indie" art style with a very Mirrors Edge color scheme, that just works and looks beautiful! For me this game filled a hole for a drifting game after Rockstar ruined GTA5's driving mechanics and didn't allow for drifting of any kind.Pros:- Best soundtrack in an indie game since Minecraft- Best driving mechanics in any PC game EVER- Realistic and awesome vehicle sounds and crash sounds- Beautiful art style and color scheme- Global leaderboards make for endless replayability!- Good variety of vehicles, from a classic 180SX (missile) to the powerful WRX Wagon (hooniwagon)- 5 worlds full of fun "missions" as well as a helpful tutorialCons:- Only 5 worlds, even though they are all quite large, I would like to see more added. I would pay $10 for a DLC pack with 5 more worlds.- Scoring mechanics are kinda iffy, often destroying your built-up multiplyer even when you are constantly drifting or just because you barely tap a wall.9.5/10, HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!! For only CAD$12, how can you go wrong with a game like this?

content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												"Full grown man playing with hotwheels on the kitchen floor: the game"I mean this as an enormous compliment. I'm only a couple hours deep, but this game really wears its heart on its sleeve. If you've ever played any top-down racers or classic grand theft auto, you'll understand the controls immediately, and they feel good.Now, the point of this game is stressed explicitly several times, it's not about speed. It's about control. Your performance is scored by how well you can control your drift down a straight away and through turns. The concepts and controls are very simple, and the early levels are very welcoming to new players. That being said, the skill ceiling is actually quite high. This is definitely a game of skill. If challenge doesn't interest you, or if you've been beating your head againt the wall on a difficult course, there is a free mode that lets you loose in a sandbox with ramps and obstacles to play with. This is the section that I liken to playing with hot wheels on the kitchen floor (it's exactly as fun as it sounds).I would say this game definitely has an appeal to people that enjoy high-skill game play that has a rapid loop of retrying until you get it perfect (ex: Trials, Hotline Miami, OlliOlli, Dark Souls)I just compared playing with Hot Wheels cars on the kitchen floor to Dark Souls.....

content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												Absolute Drift is an interesting top down car game, that focuses much more on drifting and the control of the car, rather than racing. You'll be doing your best to drift around corners, doing donuts, and fish tails in order to score as much points and to accomplish as much tasks as possible.


YouTube™ Video: Absolute Drift: Impressions (Drift driving adventure game, indie,  gameplay, and review) 

			Views: 1,576		

			Absolute Drift: Impressions (Drift driving adventure game, indie, gameplay, and review) Absolute Drift is an interesting top down driving indie game, that focuses on drifting more than racing.		

Once in the game you'll be thrown into a somewhat open world where you'll be doing various tasks, such as ramp jumping, donuts, fish tails, and other drifting and driving challenges. Once the section of the map's tasks are complete, it'll open up new areas of the game. While exploring this semi-open world, you'll also be given the opportunity to enter one of it's many mini-missions where you'll be aiming for high scores on the leader board. The game also features multiple car models, and colour and pattern customization as well.The biggest hurdle to Absolute Drift is it's learning curve. It's not an easy game to master and make little concession to beginning or even intermediate players. The controls are difficult at first, as the car feel very differnt from other driving games, and the ground feels something like ice. Spinning out and losing control of your car will probably be your first 30 minutes or more of your experiance. This might prove frustrating to players who don't play a lot of driving games (like me) but when you start to get the hang of things, and the small amounts of progress that you make in your driving ability really does feel rewarding. How ever, if you are a fan of driving games, it's focus on high teir play may very well be an attraction to you. The game also looks great, as it's polished and clean look catches the eye, with it's minimalist design, with great music that suit the game's look and feel. Infact, the game's OST was one of the main motavators to push through the initial frustration of the controls. I just wanted to keep playing so I could keep listening to the amazing sound track.Overall, Absolute Drift is an interesting car game that I mostly enjoyed. I loved the presentation, I love the music, I love the concept. The only thing holding me back from enjoying the game to it's full potential is my sucky driving in combination with the game's extremly high learning curve.Pros- Great visuals- Amazing sound track- An interesting concept- High teir driving fans would probably love the challenge levelCons- Extremely high learning curve- Frustrating at times

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												Before we begin, let me first clarify my play time. At most I could say I got about 15 minutes of amusement before I became dreadfully bored. In the end, I was obsessed with completing a perfect game. Additionally my desire for achievement hunting came only after a 3hr idle for cards.**EDIT**Just happened to notice that I no longer have a perfect game thanks to an update...Luckily enough time has passed that I feel no urge what so ever to return and reclaim my perfect game. Further proof this game as little to offer. And before you post - Yes! I am a little salty because they stole my perfect game >.< **END EDIT**I'll condense the rest of my review to just the cons as you can read positive review for the pros.Problems:Aside from the repetitive "challenges" the game has no real focus other than drifting and comparing you score to other players. I guess that wouldn't be such a bad thing, especially if that is all you want, but for me I like interactive game play that goes further than a global score board.Lastly I want to say that I am not a fan of the drift mechanics. Now I am not saying I am any form of an expert on how drifting truly works, but I can state that for some reason I didn't find the drifting in this game fun. They're O.K. - just not for me. It felt like I had to learn a whole new set of drifting rules for a game I am never going to play again.Provisos:I would change my recommendation for the following type of gamer/situation;Perfectionist - Achievements were easy to get. (EDIT: Recent change/update stole my Completion)HUGE fan of any form of drifting - Drifting is in the title after all.Fan of Indie Games - For an indie game, it is not that bad.Massive sale - Anything $3 or under.

Posted: January 4
												This is one of the games where you can have fun, just drift around and listen to perfectly fitting soundtracks. If you're going to for challenges and achievements, though, prepare yourself to lots of despair and maybe even anger. Once you find the "eureka" moment of how to accelerate and steer without spinning out and/or (mostly and) crashing into walls, you'll find another difficult task how to balance these two into one beautiful long drift you've been waiting for.I was originally playing with keyboard, but when finally arrived my Steam Controller, I switched without any hesitation. I must say, playing with controller is a whole new perception of the game. And this comes from a person who never played with controller before.Game itself is minimalistic, easy to play and hard to master. There's also a set of soundtracks which didn't get repetitive even after nearly 10 hours of gameplay.I got this game on HumbleBundle during some sale, but I wouldn't hesitate and buy it for the full price. If you like this kind of games, you won't be disappointed.9/10 would even slightly touch the wall and lose score multiplier again.

An Arcade Drifting Game


YouTube™ Video: Absolute Drift || Arcade Drifting Game 

			Views: 88		

			#absolutedrift http://store.steampowered.com/app/320140/ Add me on Steam: http://steamcommunity.com/id/desolater_iv + A great minimalistic style that looks very pleasing to the eye + Fantastic...		

+ A great minimalistic style that looks very pleasing to the eye+ Fantastic soundtrack with the ability to skip tracks whenever you like+ Free-roaming drifting challenges, with a few high flying ramps+ The gameplay is pretty fun especially when you get good enough to make long drifts without spinning out- The controls hold this game back a bit. It's actually deceptively difficult to learn how to make good drifts without spinning out or losing control. I feel like this is mainly because the steering is so limited, yet while drifting it's incredibly easy to spin out. This can be irritating, especially for new players.- All in all, the game feels a bit repetitive as you mainly repeat score attack challenges or do a variety of little challenges like drifting between objects or jumping off a few ramps.- Feels a bit unrewarding as you progress through the game. I mean there's no real goal or sense of victory while doing any of the challenges. The drift tracks are focused on competing on the leaderboards but there's no score goal to advance, so it really doesn't matter how well you do.

YouTube™ Video: Absolute Drift: Zen Edition [Game Review] 

			Views: 838		

			My review of "Absolute Drift: Zen Edition", an arcade driving game developed and published by Funselektor Labs Inc. Copy supplied by developer.		

Game: Absolute Drift: Zen EditionGenre: Arcade DrivingDeveloper: Funselektor Labs Inc. Publisher: Funselektor Labs Inc. Copy supplied by developerAbsolute Drift: Zen Edition is an arcade driving game developed and published by Funselektor Labs Inc. GRAPHICSThe game uses an isometric camera, giving it an instant old-school feel. The use of white and red in the maps helps you relax, while also highlighting challenges and important items.GAMEPLAYThe game is all about one thing: drifting. After having played some tutorials that help you understand the controls, you can play either Free Roam (where there are challenges to complete and objects to collect) or Events (which are maps where you have to complete certain tasks, like drifting for over 10 seconds or spinning into a circle for 3 seconds).The controls are deceptively easy, but the more you play the more you understand how deep and sensitive they are. Mastering the art of drifting sure ain't easy. So, I think that playing with a controller is mandatory, because when I tried playing with the keyboard it was almost impossible to complete even a single task.CHALLENGEThe Free Roam mode is very fun and relaxing, while the Events are damn hard and challenging (especially if you still can't drift that well), but thankfully only a couple of tracks were really frustrating.SOUNDThe soundtrack by C41 and Nyte is incredibly relaxing, and listening to it while exploring playing Free Roam immerses you into the driving quite a lot. And, for once, the sound effects of the car aren't annoying.REPLAYABILITYEven though the game itself will take you around three hours to complete, you can unlock new cars and paint jobs, and you can try improving your high-scores and completing all the tasks.Overall, if you are a fan of driving games but don't want the pressure of actually taking part in races, definitely play Absolute Drift: Zen Edition: it is relaxing and it has some of the deepest drifting mechanics I have played.Story: n/aGraphics: 8Gameplay: 7.5Challenge: 10Sound: 9Replayability: 8ENJOYMENT: 8FRUSTRATION: 7Follow me on Twitter: @nickygra97Subscribe to my channelLike on FacebookJoin my Steam group

Posted: January 25, 2016
												This game shows how I would imagine drifting in Heaven looks like. I bought it for 7€ and it was absolutly worth it (even the full price). Very relaxing to just slide around on the wide areas. The art style is probably not everybodys favorite... still gives a good contrast between floor and skid marks.Pros: + Very nice drifting feel/good physics+ easy enough to learn, but still a challenge to master+ sounds are perfect (great Turbo whistle and blow-offs)+ the map has a great selection of places, from a harbour to a mountain lake+ the music fits the game perfectly (in my mind)+ has 3 modes: Drift Courses, Driftkhana, Mountain Drifts+ Leaderboard for the events (weirdly Takumi Fujiwara is on first place)Cons: - a bit short- can be very precise with some tricks (wall tap)!!Dont forget that it was made by only 2 Persons!!Update Zen Edition: (16th of August 2016)The Zen Edition was an Update that brought in a considerable amount of new things to do including:* A new tutorial mode to help YOU be a better and more skilled driver* Drift Lines, which are a new way to get drift points -> clip them completely for a big point gain* New 'Midnight Challenges' which are mountain drift tracks at night* You can now watch yourself drifting with the new replays* An overhaul of the controls* 'Event Challenges' give you 5 tasks per track, from easy to very hard, to do -> more gameplay* New achievements for the challengesWith the Zen Edition the game gets much more content and some goals you can achieve. And the Midnight challenges give experienced drivers/drifters a real challenge. And dont forget that it still costs the same as before. Also dont forget to...KeepDriftingFun

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												In Absolute Drift you drive a little car trying to get as high as possible score by sliding your car aka drifting and spinning. It is a single player game but you can compete with your friends by a ranking system - after each driven event you see your rank depending on your best score from drifting. You can drive a free roam also. In free roam you are driving on map divided in different but connected worlds with amount of missions. If you complete all missions including drifting, spinning and jumping, following world is unlocked and you may drive in. Or you can just drift freely in the map.You may change color of your car, use keyboard/xbox/ps controllers, choose manual or automatic transmission, steer assist on/off, steering sensitivity and vibration for your controller. Could be nice with wheel support too.The game has nice simple and clean graphic and gameplay is very smooth. It could have profiles for different people playing on a single computer or just playing it again and again, because if you complete a mission in free roam, looks like you cannot reset your game progress to be able to play it again. This is about missions in free roam not about events which you can repeat indefinitely.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												This game is really cool but it is hard as HELL. It's about driving a car with like grease on the tires and you have to slide around literally every corner and jump through a bunch of little hoops to try to score points. It's simple, polished and about as pure as a game gets but in spite of the claim in the title that it's a zen game, it is super frustrating.The first hour of this game was just me going "jesus christ how the hell can anyone be good at this." then i kind of learned that i had to throw all my natural impulses in racing games out the window, drive a little slower, and then I still ♥♥♥♥ed up about a million times. The first actual track in the game is just a standard oval but it honestly took me nearly 45 minutes to get a relatively reasonable score and complete 4/5 track objectives. And maybe the fact that it requires you to reassess your assumptions about something and respond to it more instinctually means it is a little more zen than a lot of things that claim to be zen.Maybe my biggest beef is the music and some of the sound effects are at least a little obnoxious, but it's a pretty legit good game. I may actually keep it installed and play around with it. Recommend at a discount or in a bundle, but only if you look at the trailers and think it looks fun. Also that♥♥♥♥♥♥in the trailer? you won't be doing that right away. Kind of makes me think of the earlier iterations of the Trials series in a lot of ways, if that means anything to anybody.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												Drifting is the name of the game here and that's precisely what you're gonna get. Drift around that pole! Sweet!Now jump over that lake! Awesome!Get them donuts going on that helipad! Cool!That's basically it. There's a free-roam mode which consists of several zones with mini-objectives as well as separate events scattered around. Get to the zone, complete objectives, unlock the next one - repeat until you're the drift master. Events are instances in which you can rack up your personal score and compete with other players via the leaderboards. You have 3 lap drift courses of varying difficulty, driftkhanas, which essentially are closed off arenas in which you race against time to get the highest score possible and you have drift tracks in which you go from point A to point B and get as many points as you can along the way. The game is short, if you're aiming to 'complete' it. If you're here for the pleasure of drifting though, you can spend hours upon hours perfecting your skills. The presentation is fantastic with very slick, clean and, most importantly, clear visuals. Music is very catchy and complements the picture in the best possible way. All in all - if you like stylish visuals, racing and drifting, treat yourself with this little gem.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												ZEN EDITION UPDATE: I gave another try to Absolute Drift after the Zen Edition update this week. Being able to play it with the controller definitely makes it less bad to play. However, I don't feel the drive model has been changed. It still needs improvements in my opinion to be enjoyable.Using analog controls definitely does the difference. But it's still a real pain to just enjoy the game drifting. I know the game is more focused towards highscorers and achieving perfection through repetition, but my expectations were that I would be able to just drift smoothly easily, even if not in an efficient way. Or at least doing it in the easy mode.After the 2 hours I've spent on the update, it turns out I had a way better time in hard mode than in easy mode. I still had to be fully attentive to not mess up, as hitting a wall always breaks the rythm of the track, as well as ending up in a spin. Recovering from a spin is a hassle, you can't quickly go reverse-turn-forward using the car's inertia (and same for the other way around).Regarding controls, having multiple layout for controllers is better, but still, none of them suited me. I would have prefered to have the option to set the handbrake as LT. I personally can't handle acceleration + handbrake with the same hand. So I ended up only using acceleration and rarely brake/reverse. And you still can't change the settings while racing or free-roaming. And you can't reset the settings either.So eventhough this update has brought improvements to the game, it hasn't done so for it's core gameplay. I've personally enjoyed it a bit more, but I would still not recommend it unless you are a highscrorer, love repeting something unnecessarily hard to master and cramped hands after 1-2h of gameplay.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ORIGINAL VERSION:I started playing that game because I heard some good about it, feeled like my jam and I had it in an humble bundle. Once I started the game and started playing it in free roam, I really wanted to like it. The art style is good, the music is great and I like the concept. But after a few tracks and missions I realized the drive model wasn't up to par with the rest of the game. I played the whole game in easy. I tried different sensitivity settings but not much because it's really a hassle to change it: you have to EXIT TO MENU to go to settings, you can't even change it while playing!! I also had to play with keyboard because of the problem with my Xbox One controller. I went to the forum topic in the community hub and followed the different tips to make it work but none of it did the trick. It's the first time I see a game do that bad with a standard controller.I forced myself to go through the 5 worlds in free roam to try and get better. I did a bit, especially with The Missile and Das Whip, which are way easier to control than the previous cars in my opinion. I also felt quite good playing the mountain drift tracks, which only appear starting with world 4! And after getting to world 3 I stopped doing the driftkhana tracks which were just pointless and not enjoyable at all to me.Wanted to like it, loved the looks, loved the sounds, hated the driving model which is the key part in this game ><. I was so tensed during the game to not mess up my driving that my arm now hurts after only 1.5h of continuous play. So if you like to master broken games, go for it. If you don't, go look for another one.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												Sometimes in your haste to enjoy a game, you don't give it a good chance. My first time playing this game (well, maybe my first hour) was me being really frustrated at not being able to drift, not being able to control my car, and generally not being able to make it the way I wanted. I pictured a game that was more about relaxing and leisurely drifting through tracks or endless highways, but was wrong.The thing is, I don't mind being wrong; Absolute Drift has a great mechanics system that rewards you for putting time in and learning how your car works. This is likely as close to it comes to the real world, too, as no one is necessarily a Drift King the first time they try. The more time I spent tweaking the settings (note: you may find Hard controls with 100% steering sensitivity better if you're used to drifting in other Arcade-y racers) the more I felt myself gradually getting better.The cool thing is, every time I boot the game up now I genuinely need to warm up, as my first ten minutes are me reacclimating to how my car controls. This isn't a bad thing at all; again, it rewards patience and persistence, and the first time you actually do pull off something awesome (be it a chain drift, or even a drift that's challenging things a little too far) you feel amazing.Essentially this game rewards mastery of the mechanics and the time it takes to learn them. My main complaints are that I could do without the time limits, objectives and feedback during some event courses: I would love to be able to turn it off and just practice drifting (or just doing it therapeutically) without the game telling me I'm dropping combos or running out of time.I also think this game (especially when it's called a Zen Edition) could use some procedurally-generated endless highway that either has a difficulty you specify or one that changes organically; I LOVE the mountain and midnight courses in this game, but find them woefully too short.Great game, but you need to be patient with it. If you do, you'll find awesome, rewarding moments.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Absolute Drift is not a standard racing game, it's heavily focused on the handling mechanics of a drift car with a quite steep learning curve. Previous experience with racing titles and real life knowledge of how drifting should work will definitively help to get over the first approach to the controls.Don't even bother using a keyboard, this game is best played with a controller that has analog input for the throttle control, a xbox 360 controller is just fine. In addition, I strongly suggest to try the manual transmission and disabling the assisted steering in order to have more direct control to the car.Thematically the game is full of reference from the iconic "Initial D" manga to the Japanese drifting car culture in general. Overall the game aesthetic is minimalistic and beautiful with an awesome soundtrack to complete the well polished package. The only complain I have is the "white buildings on white roads" which can cause confusion, but admittedly I'm playing on an awful monitor so your experience may vary. I strongly suggest this title to every car enthusiast. Just the turbo whistle when you lift of is enough to justify the purchase. This game also teaches you how to quickly deliver tofu on top of a mountain. (untrue)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20
												There is a learning curve with this game, but I'm extremely impressed with the physics.  It walks you through the basic drift, and some point earning tactics, and then just let you run free with secrets to find, fun little games and puzzles to play, an impressive range for such a simple game.  I call it simple but the mastery of the drift in this game can be difficult to attain, but once it clicks, it's almost a zen state with the great trance sort of electronic score.  The music is great, and it really adds to the atmosphere.  This is one of those games you can play for 15 mins, or hours. (Sometimes the shorter sessions are due to frustration lol :-P on those days when you just can't make the drift work, and there will be those days unless you really do master it).  Great game all around, be cool to see this on portable platform(s) *cough* 3DS *cough* ;-) I think this would be a killer 3DS game, the style of the game would meld great with some slick 3D effects. I know it would probably be a complete rewrite, but one can hope... right?  Thanks for the great game!

												If you've held off on buying this game because of concerns about length, now's a good time to dive in. The new challenges are difficult but rarely unreasonable, and the tutorial tracks are a great way to learn the mechanics.The mechanics really are the star of this game, and they are a joy. This is one of the few games I've spent hours in after 100%ing, just because it feels so nice to play. Zen is a good descriptor. Something about controlling your momentum while getting the right curve just feels right. The minimalist asthetic is also very well done.Even if you don't care for the idea of "drifting," I highly recommend you grab a controller and give this one a shot. You'll know within two hours whether or not it's for you.

Posted: December 3, 2015
												My 9th most played game on steam and one of the most entertaining games I've played in a long time.Pros+++ Steep learning curve. Modern games tend to be way too simplified in terms of mechanical skill required to play in order to appeal much casual audience as possible. Absolute drift is fairly hard to learn, harder to master while keeping it fun doing that.+ Driving is really damn fun. Pulling out that perfect drift is reward in itself.+ Leaderboards. The main reason of my game time.+ Minimalistic Graphics. Result is a game that is not power hungry and looks nice and clean.+ Soundtrack. Awesome and chill.+ Initial D references and AE86. Love it.Cons-If you are looking for story, better go looking at other direction. There isn't one aside being told to become "Drifting master" at the beginning.-Short campaign mode of 30-120 minutes depending how you play it.-Even though having minimalistic graphics i'd really like seeing some scenery around the maps.-Performance issues in couple of maps.-For casual play the price point might not be justified for the reasons addressed above.Overall: Really nice drifting game that hooks you in with it's mechanical play.

Posted: June 21, 2016
												Fun little game that is surprisingly hard to master.Though 100%'ing the game and achievements can be done in a single sitting, the quick climb to becoming a "drift master" is a good challenge. Cars are loose and easy to drift but hard to control. But controllable they are! This results in it feeling quite satisfying when you string together some tricks and turns and get your combo score flying high. But it can be quite frustrating when, more often than not, you don't keep control. The art and music combo is almost hypnotizing as you get mesmerized. But losing control and crashing your vehicle keeps you grounded in reality.It really could have used a bit more depth. Overall suffers from that feeling of input lag just by it's style of driving. But this bogged feeling, whether my imagination or not, extends to the menus as well. Things could've been more crisp in that respect. And it is quite short. 2.3hrs to 100% for me. Not even enough time to "farm" all the Steam Cards. I don't feel the need to beat my scores so I don't really see any replayability here. It could've used some sort of racing mode with NPCs or local versus. Would've been a great callback to a MicroMachines or OffRoad feel. Spoiler warning; The ending dialogue hint towards a rally themed sequel gets my nerd senses tingling and I hope to see that realized one day as the base here is exceptional.There's definitely something here. Maybe not a ton, but something. Fun to be had for an afternoon. A perfect bundle game but might have trouble standing up to scrutiny as a lone purchase.

Posted: January 4, 2016
												Written after two free roam playthroughs using a controller once and keyboard once:After seeing this game on sale for the winter sale I decided that I should buy it. The two things that caught my eye were first, drifting. As someone who considers themself a fan of drifting I was really interested in the physics of how the drifting was especially in comparison to my favorite game to drift which is Forza.  The second thing is the art. The art behind the game is incredibly minimalist, the simplicity caught my eye because it rivals Mirrors Edge almost perfect in style and coloring.  That being said I took the dive on and indie game, which is something I do not do often.Currently, I have spent most of my time playing the freeroam, and just want to address that as of now. I will certainly come back for an edit with more of my opinion based on the "events".  The freeroam alone is great. The settings within the game are really quite enjoyable while work perfectly with the concept of the game. The missions you do aren't to insane, most are easy and they are more of a relaxing type of fit for the game. As someone who generally likes games to be more difficult it was kind of disappointing, but it seems like that will really take affect later in the "event" section.The physics of the game is amazing.  I really enjoyed how drifting felt from a top down view and found that it wasn't too difficult to grasp but was hard enough that I really liked to get to know the way it works.  I would say, that the physics are on par with other "simulation" games, like Forza. They are more forgiving certainly, but for this genre it works perfectly!The other thing I would really like to talk about is the controls. I have seen some other reviews addressing them and say really this game is best with a controller and how the keyboard is definetly worse. So I started the game using a xbox one controller. I really enjoyed it and I found it was much easier to learn off the bat and was easily grasped.  The thing I would like to say is as great as the controller was, I personally enjoyed using my keyboard much more. For some reason, the controller felt much "slower" as in, i felt like the car it self was slow in response and speed (not in a bad way, it was just different than the keyboard), so when I played through a second time I decided to use the keyboard. The controls are extremely simple, the hardest thing is just getting used to how to multitask and use multiple buttons all at the same time.  For instance, it is weird using all of the arrow keys when counter-steering it is possible to oversteer or understeer so you have to make micro adjustments while still throttling and handbraking. So that was hard to grasp immediately, but after 10 minutes or so, it becomes great! I really enjoyed using the keyboard to play, actually even more than the controller.The only con is the length of the game, it is quite easy to just zip right through the freeroam mode, but if you are someone who likes games that rely on leaderboards than this is certainly a good option.  Although it is short, I will say that replay value of free roam in my opinion is quite high because you wont remember all of the missions unless you have a photographic memory. Overall, if you are looking for a good drifting game with a great physics engine and beautiful art (including music as well) you have found it right here.  I would say this is a must purchase driving game!

Posted: June 25, 2016
												The main campaign is pretty short and I'm really bad at this game....so why am I thumbing it up? Well...the main mechanic (drifting a car) has a learning curve that is fun to do. Yes, I slam in every wall I can find and even some more, but Absolute drift doesn't beat me over the head with it. Rather the contrary: the way everything is set up, this is more like a playground than you having to be somewhere. And if the campaign was longer (even twice the size wouldn't be called big), I'm sure I would have gotten better (I mean...I started out as "absolutely terrible", so I made progress ;) ).The atmosphere is what you get in the preview: minimalistic (near abstract) visuals and an absolutely awesome soundtrack. I absolutely like it.The thing is that I'm not sure who to really recommend it to. Top down racers were always hard to handle (I mean...I loved super off road on the SNES exactly because inevitably someone of the group would drive COMPLETELY off), and with no other car in sight, this game is like the test drive for these other games.There's certainly mastery in here. I just think I didn't come close to it (I usually ended the races throughout the game in the bottom 10%). For those who find mastery like this engaging, I guess? :-)

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												As someone who's used to long hours of forza with all assist turned off, manual with clutch, and 1100Hp death rockets i was hoping i'd be able to feather the throttle and go pro mode on this game. alas, it's more of a mash the gas- don't gentle rub the break in an oversteer  or you'll come to a complete stop arcady type of racer. which isn't the worst thing. A) I'm sure they didn't have turn 10 money to call in goodyear and create some nasa grade handling system and B) I'm sure it makes the game more approachable for beginners. I personally found it hard to spin out and lose control cataclysmically like i often do in sim racing games, so it is quite forgiving.The challenges in the game are also quite forgiving. you can basically bash the walls on every object you need to drift under or next to and it gives it to you, which is awesome. it's a zenful game. it's something you play to mellow out and clear your head. and if it forced me to do something perfect before i could move on that would destory the balance, and I would break stuff and never play it again :)TLDR It's a peaceful, fresh, low spec zen game that is neither bad nor life changing. But for $1 on humble bundle, plus trading cards I'm very happy with my purchase. I'm sure the next time i catch a cold and im drowning in a sea of nyquil this will be one of my go to games while i feel like garbage. you can never have enough of those.

												Best drifting game I have ever seen.Simple controls and mechanics - easy to learn, yet difficult to master.Fair scoring system - if you crash, your points for the whole drift chain aren't lost. This game is where the FUN is.

Posted: September 11, 2016
												Review in a few: 


YouTube™ Video: Review in a Few: Absolute Drift 

			Views: 33		

			Here is my review in a few for Absolute Drift: Zen Edition Buy the game here: store.steampowered.com/app/320140/ My written review can be found on steam here:...		

+Visuals+Soundtrack+Steam Controller+Mad Drifts+Leaderboard asyncronous multiplayer.-No storyAbsolute Drift is a game about a man with a family to save from the Yakuza and the only bid they’ll take on their lives is if you beat their leader in a drift-off, so you play a montage of training until the final battle scene like every kung fu movie.  Wait that’s not right…  So there’s no backstory.  You’re just a car with mad drifts.It’s a very simple concept, drift as much as you can, chain together drifts, and get points.  The more points you get, the higher your score, the farther up the leaderboards you go.  There’s a large open-world area where you can complete challenges like drifting around certain objects, performing jumps, and collecting spinning plus-signs.  It’s sectioned off into areas, and you must complete objectives in each area before advancing to the next one resulting in solid progression as your personal skill improves.There are dedicated tracks with leaderboards (as mentioned earlier) that allow you to compete against others asynchronously, which are placed around the open world map for you to find.  If exploration is less your thing however, you can find the tracks on the main menu as well and jump right in.  These tracks can have one of two types: open areas with trick spots, and race tracks that record both your time and your drifts.The controls are easy to pick up, tough to master -- Or maybe I just suck.  It’s definitely not a game to play keyboard only, as feathering drifts is nigh impossible, so a controller of some form is a must.  It also has some really nice feedback on how good your drift is through rumble, which translates well onto a steam controller.Graphics wise, it’s visually pleasing.  It’s very easy to tell what is where and what’s important, and there is never enough on screen to get busy.  With a pleasantly good looking drift line showing your mad skills, you can watch your past as you tear up the present.Overall it’s an enjoyable game and worth picking up on sale for a few hours of fun.  It’s not going to keep you gripped for a dozen hours, but it’s better than your average movie with a lower admittance fee.
