Posted: April 26
Absolute HellThis is a top down game about drifting. It has simplistic graphics with a touch of color here and there that works perfectly for this type of game. In free roam you have to complete challenges within the specific world in order to gain access to the next. There are 5 worlds in total which are pretty easy and don't take all that long to complete. The real challenge lies in the events mode which you can access through free roam but they are all scattered around the different worlds so it makes more sense to just do them from the events button in the main menu instead. The skill progression is pretty hard to begin with when doing some challenges like drifting close to poles but after a few hours practice it becomes second nature.The Dark Souls Boss of this game is the "Complete 2 perfect lines" challenge. It took me 2 hours just to complete 2 challenges with this in it. The thing is you only get 1 chance to do it right and you need to drift at a perfect speed and angle. Many many times I completed the first one and just couldn't do the second because I didn't know the right angle, had too much or not enough speed, over drifted or just fell OF THE EDGE. Everything else in the game is pie compared to this.There are a few different types of cars you unlock which seems to all have slightly different speeds & amounts of drift as well as some different paints & designs. It can become a little repetitive when doing all the events because they are pretty much all the same type of thing on a different map design but it’s generally a fun and relaxed game to just chill and then almost break your keyboard when you spend an hour straight trying to do the 2nd perfect line!7.8/10- Very Chill but also Rage Inducing

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												Short (less than three hours to 100% achievement) though very enjoyable game with an XBOX360 controller. The "end game" is attempting higher scores on specific tracks while the "main game" is progress through 6 worlds, with the 6th being no more than a play to wrap the game up and roll credits.Don't buy this game if you're expecting realistic physics or even blow-off valve accuracy - you contantly paint black tyre marks which gives a nice artistic feel to your movements, though I would have much preferred a way to only show tyre marks only when actually skidding. This isn't a drifting simulator. This isn't a racing game. This is a chilled out explorer and you play the role of an AE86.I hope they make Absolute Drift 2 and give more substance. An ability to modify the car that would have an effect on the physics would be cool as well as camera angles. Obviously multiplayer for some door-on-door drifing action would be great and anything to make this a game that you'd want to go back to once you unlocked everything that needed to be unlocked.Is it worth US$11.99? For a three-hour ish game? That's only a maybe. It had been on my wish list for a long time and it blew me away seeing it on HumbleBundle so keep an eye out - this game is definately worth it if you can get it discounted.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
												Game has a learning curve but it's a lot of fun when you get past the frustration of running into walls. Once you get good at the game you feel like one cool dude. >8-)*EDIT* Beta update has fixed issues such as losing combos from jumps and it's now easier to keep your combo in general. Also its added a clutch and restart button :ok_hand: I finished the game (100% Acheivement) using Automatic and Medium difficulty. However you'll get the most out of this game using Manual gearing and Hard difficulty which allows much more control, though I don't recommend using these settings untill you get the basics down. Some basic understanding about how cars work and also drifting definetely helps but is not essential. There is an excellent guide on the community forums which helped me out going into manual gearing. I went from bad scores to consistantly getting top 1% thanks to the guides and a lot of practice. A lot of the replayability is going for personal bests. Though it is a bit frustrating at times seeing the top 8 scores are usually 2x my best at the least. Also driftkana is a lot of fun but the best scores are just exploiting the best area to do one big continuous donut which isnt the games highpoint (but still heaps of fun :p). Controller is recommended but honestly not needed. There are videos of top scores on youtube from people who are using a keyboard.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												This is a really fun game, reminiscent of Drift Legends, a game I used to play on iPhone.It doesn't hold your hand; it gives you a few pointers, and then lets you get into it.For most people who play car games on a regular basis, it's easy to get into, but still hard to master. For those who don't play car games, you're probably not going to enjoy it as much - read most of the negative reviews - they complain about not being able to handle. I say, GET BETTER!Graphically, it's very minimalistic isometric style (even the menu) - much like Kill The Bad Guy - and it works most of the time, except your car can get hidden behind building at times: this is probably the only bit of frustration that could have been avoided had they designed it so buildings get translucent when the car is behind them.Sounds work - again, very minimalistic, but they work - and the engine sounds are unique as well, not all boring same-as.Physics are pretty good, and the cars all handle different - some more different than others - you will want to experiment to find which one fits you best (I really liked the Hoonivan).The only real cons I have are the aforementioned inability to see cars behind buildings, and the listed retail price (I got it for $1, but it's probably worth $5, not the price listed on Steam). I've played about 7hrs, and seen all there is, the only thing to keep me coming back is to increase my scores on levels.Conclusion: great little drift game, definitely worth playing. It's in a bundle right now, so snap it up.EDIT: I thought I'd mention it IS playable with keyboard, but A LOT easier to play with a controller, because you really need throttle control (like most car games).

 General Good game to lose a few hours although over priced for the amount of actual game play hours. UI The UI is simple and easy to use. The graphics matches well with the style of the game. After a while you will become used the mechanics and start getting decent runs and scores. However I do feel that the game is too pricey for what you get. I wouldn’t recommend this game

												“I am a leaf on the wind, watch how I drift.” I played this one back when it was an Alpha probably a year ago. It’s still just as much fun as I remember it being back then. I love the open structure / free roam nature of it. Progressing through it feels like a natural evolution instead of blocked off levels. And that art style... it's just gorgeous. This is definitely one I can see coming back to and replaying even after I beat it. Even after you finish the specific objectives it's a lot of fun to simply drive around the map.Video Review:

Posted: November 16, 2016
												If you are a racing game enthusiast then you likely have the skillset and experience required to dive in and enjoy this game but a more casual person like myself it is pretty much unplayable. If you are a patient person looking for a challenge or timewaster you might consider this, even without a racing game resume.- Lack of information in HUD, not even basics like what speed you are going or what gear you are using.- "Tutorial" is a challenge room not a tutorial, it's like throwing a baby in a lake and hoping it learns how to swim.- No practice area/training room to compensate for the problems stated above.- As the title suggests drifting is crucial but not taught in the game and this is a technique, not a button you press so combining all the above problems I just can't recommend this game.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												Highly addictive "multiple try" perfectionist type of game. Nice clean and minimalistic artstyle. No night/dark mode. Runs perfectly, other than the occasional smoke caused performance drop. Locked at 60fps by default, no option to change it in the settings menu. Sometimes I feel like the point registering system isn't quite accurate, as you can slide at quite an angle without it ever counting as a drift. Same goes for the point system in the end of a combo - when your combo ends, and you hit another drift just after, it can take quite a while for it to start registering it and giving you points. I had the infamous Xbox One controller bug on Windows 10 and trying to fix this issue by the standard troubleshooting guide yielded no results, neither did any of the publicly available beta options help. Got in contact the developer and they were kind enough to give the beta code for the Zen edition. After that, no problems. Props for the quick answer.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2016
I can't recommend this game for the following reasons:   - Short gameplay I finished the game and all achievements but 1 within 5 hours, and the last achievement would take 5x the time it took to get the others. So it doesn't have much gameplay at all.  - Gets repetetive Very repetetive, nothing is new introduced the further you progress into the game except for the first few worlds. The last ones are just super boring (which cause you to skip levels = less gameplay) - Skip the game? If you'd like you could skip all levels and just complete some tasks to head straight on to the next world. Did they realize that people would get so bored playing it so they just added a skip?  - Very difficult It's very challenging, which I suppose could be a positive thing, but I've completed the game and I still feel as bad as I did when I started out. I didn't learn much at all and I dont get good scores on any maps, even though that buddha told me that I'm a "Drifting Master" at the end of the game.  - Default settings suck The default settings are terrible - atleast they were for me. With "easy" mode, drifting assist and 50% turn sensetivity toggled (they are toggled by default) I found it super hard to drift, it felt like I had no control over the car whatsoever. I had to experiment with the settings and ended up putting on "hard" mode, no drift assist and 80% turn sensetivity to make it feel natural. I don't know, it was just really time consuming and annoying.  - Repetetive music All the songs sound the same. (People tagged this with great soundtrack, ouch) + Graphics The only positive thing that I can think of are the simple graphics, I really enjoy those. It looks pretty neat.(But it hurts your eyes if you play with a white car, since everything else is white aswell. Lost my car a few times before painting it black) Conclusion I suppose if you really have no other games to play, you like games that you will have to practice for, you got your own music, you like racing games and this game is on 80% sale or in a humble bundle - It's fine to buy it!Otherwise, don't. Sorry for possible grammar mistakes.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												I’m usually not much a fan of driving games these days. I used to play them a lot more when I was younger but at some point I just stopped having fun facing the same challenges again and again in every driving game. But I did enjoy drifting mechanics from time to time and since I got this game in a Humble Bundle, I decided to check it out.Unfortunately, I can’t really say I was having a great time with it. The first problem I had with the game were the controls. Giving cars realistic physical properties is difficult and more importantly, difficult for the player to control. Which is why most driving games focus on fun, arcadey feeling driving that doesn’t challenge the player too much with real world physics. Absolute Drift unfortunately goes a completely different route, eschewing physical car mechanics as well as typical tightly controlled driving of other games. Your car is almost always drifting. You can barely drive in a straight line and then enter a curve without the car breaking out at the back. This is also explained by the extremely wide turning radius that you drive while trying your best not to break out.Then again, drifting is the main attraction of this game so it makes somewhat sense for your car to be easily turned sideways. The problem is that the controls feel extremely floaty. Acceleration is slow as if your car weighs twice as much as a real car. And I sort of suspect that may be the case, since the easiest way to get a physics engine to behave this erratic is by increasing the mass of an object and then increasing the torque of the motor providing it with energy. This leads to very hard to learn drifting mechanics that can lead to much frustration. And I know some people will inevitably like it this way, if the scores on the leaderboards are anything to go by. But I just found it annoying. And this leads me to my next complaint: The camera. The game utilizes a bird’s-eye perspective which means when you’re driving towards the camera the controls are reversed and foreshortening makes it difficult to make out where you are in relation to the borders of the tracks. I would’ve much preferred a typical racing game camera hovering behind the car or at least one that follows the rotation of your car.But all of that could be forgiven if the game had actual content. Unfortunately, it doesn’t. There are plenty of levels there. But drifting around them is the only thing you do. There are no challenges beyond comparing your score to the global leaderboards. Coupled with the very minimalist aesthetic, that makes this game look extremely empty. If I didn’t know better, I’d assume it was still in early access. Which it very well might be, since the developers are adding new features with the upcoming Zen edition. And honestly, to me there isn’t much incentive to doing something very limited over and over again.The devs also highlight car customization and free-roaming areas as features and these are just not enough. You get to paint your car in a few different colors and that’s it. Free-roam is just an empty overworld filled with “challenges” which boil down to “drift between these two objects”, “donut around an object”, “collect 5 items in this part of the map” and “jump over an object with a ramp”. And those last two highlight how little there actually is to do in a game that is only about drifting.Honestly, if this weren’t part of a Humble Bundle that contained games I was interested in more, I probably would’ve stayed away from this game. There’s just not much there to enjoy here for me. But I do have to wonder if the price of $12 is justifiable, even though I paid nowhere near as much. Because the aesthetic is – like the developers’ previous game Race The Sun – deliberately minimalist and only features low-poly objects with basically no textures applied to them. And I can’t believe that it took that much effort to create the gameplay, since most engines nowadays feature basic driving mechanics as prefabs. If you’re into games with a very narrow focus and can deal with the repetition or if you’re the type that has to be competitive 100% of the time, you’ll find something to enjoy in Absolute Drift. But I honestly couldn’t recommend it to anybody else, since it’s just too light on content to be anything substantial.

content:
Posted: January 27
												I really liked the look of this game - something I could play when I just wanted to chill for a bit. Nice minimalistic aesthetic, relatively simple idea, good game to play when you just want to relax, I thought.Now, I'm not sure if I'm doing something wrong here, but the game never at any point actually teaches you how to drift. I've tried watching a few youtube videos of other people doing it, and it always just seems to work. I guess I'm just not a natural at it. Tha's fine, but I'd like to be taught how to improve.There are these levels labelled as "tutorials", but they are anything but. The initial "drifting tutorial" puts you on a circular track and says "drift in a circle". It doesn't actually tell me *how*. The tutorial for doing  donuts says "do donuts". The only actually useful pieces of information regarding how to drift are the quick pieces of text that appear during loading screens. Other than this, the game doesn't actually tell you how you are meant to play it.Like I said I really liked the look of this game, and really want to enjoy it. I don't doubt it's a good game if you are actually able to drift. To give this game a thumbs up rather than a thumbs down I would want to actual guidelines and tutorial within the game, so I can get to a stage where I am actually able to play it.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23
												The game itself is great. The handling is a nice balance between being realistic enough to be challenging and rewarding but is arcade-like enough to remain fun. Reason for the negative review is the game suffers from FPS issues. Considering how low-detail the graphics are, it is ridiculous how poorly the game plays. The worst part is that earlier versions of the game did not have these issues and played great on my computer.I get persistant FPS drops, enough so that it screws up my drifts and makes the game not fun to play. This is with a computer above the minimum specs and happens no matter how low I turn the graphics settings down. A FPS limiter may stabilize the frame rates, but there is no provided option for that. The dev's only suggestion is to just turn the graphics down, which does not solve my problem.  Until the FPS issues are sorted, I cannot recommend this game.

content:
Posted: February 13
												So recently nerdcubed posted a video about this game, and from what he showed it looked amazing.Don't get me wrong I love the music and art style, but the game is very repetitive and the bugs will drive you nuts.*Accelerates* *Car goes backwards*Want to brake? Yeah nah that's not happening.Going down a slope? Let's break that combo for you.Clip a kerb at the wrong angle? TO SPACE WITH YOU!!I feel as though so much more could be done with this game:-powerups---speed boost---slow down---gravity manipulation for longer jumps-racing ---same track with player-player collisions---mirrored tracksBut more importantly the player needs a reason to play. I am a completionist, and that's the only reason I kept playing; there was no story or incentive to continue playing it was just the same stuff over and over again. I go by a £1 an hour (to get 100%) and this game came just shy of that so I think it is well valued. But that time wasn't spent enjoying it, more just persevering through the pain of the bugs. The game has promise but given that it's 'released' I doubt the bugs will be fixed or anything new be added.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												It's a strange game... Obviously it is not a simulator because of top down, but the control is very focused on simulation. How does it work out as together? Not very well.The game seems very easy-to-pickup, but it really isn't- you have to focus so much, the difficulty is as bad as simulator that requires actual good controller. Also, I felt that this game is incredibly slow paced. Maybe because of how much the camera zoomed out. So wiggled some setting, I also changed difficuly to easy (shamefully) and I felt no difference from Hard difficulty. Well there are no CPUs in this game, why does this difficulty thing exist for? Scoring??Graphic is sub-par, it is the modern "low-poly" style with very minimallistic color with very little environment. I've seen it enough of this, nothing really to praise for.Music selection is great. I liked every bit of it, and it kind of connects as if there is DJ in background.The control is the same as arcade style but asks you to play like simulator.The worst part for me was the price tag. I mean, does it really worth $12? I can find numerous alternatives that may cost bit more but worth lot more than this. I tried to like it, yes, I needed to play for at least a hour to make a fair review but 20 minutes was enough torture for me. It was too challenging and really wasn't that entertaining. Some flash game plays better, and it is free.If you play a lot of racing simulation, you might like this, but why pay for limited simulator when you might already have fully-controllable simulation game? That's the confusing part.In my honesty, I don't feel like picking this up again after this review... sorry.

number of helpful: 7 of 19 people (37%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4
5/10 - Absolute Drift goes round and round and round and round...Drifting has always existed as a sort of accessory sport to traditional racing. Flashy and dangerous, drifting — the act of taking a corner so as to lose control of the back wheels and cause the car to turn sideways — prizes style and precision over speed and vehicular power. Though organized events such as the US’s Formula D series exist they are still searching for a large audience, and outside of Japan drifting remains largely a novelty, something to spice up action movies and arcade racers but rarely thought of as a legitimate sport itself.Absolute Drift (2015) feels in large part an attempt to move away from drifting as spectacle, giving you a car and a road and letting you figure out the rest. The presentation is stripped down to blunt polygonal buildings and red highlights to tell you where to go, with your car itself a nondescript toy-sized vehicle only visible by its bright paint job and lengthy tire tracks.When placed next to the gleeful excess of Need for Speed or the cartoony impossibility of Mario Kart, Absolute Drift singular focus is clean and consolidated. Drifting is the literal name of the game, so drift away to your heart’s content, careening through rectangular roads that only further emphasize the exacting grace of your curve.In a 1995 interview on Jeremy Clarkson’s Motorworld, drifting progenitor and legend Keiichi “Drift King” Tsuchiya says that one of the reasons he began drifting was to entertain the crowd during racing events. It was almost always assured he would win, so drifting became a way to put excitement back into a race where the outcome was no longer the reason to watch. This ideology is a key component to drifting’s popularity in media and as a spectator event. Watching cars go fast is fun, but watching cars go fast and take turns in ways that seem to defy the laws of physics is exhilarating.One of Absolute Drift’s earliest contradictions is in its reliance on traditional events and score attacks as means of creating a sense of progression. Absolute Drift’s prevailing methodology is that drifting is itself reward enough, and that the problem with the way drifting is used in other media is that it has become deluded by the obsessive adoration paid to it by movies like The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006). Drifting should be about the screech of your tires and the smoke of your skid marks, Absolute Drift seems to say as it positions drifting in an almost religious context (the game itself opens with a Shinto deity welcoming you into a sort of drift heaven).And yet here the game is asking you to do a donut around this building, or jump your car over this gap. The problem with Absolute Drift’s attempt at drifting solidarity is not that it doesn’t stick to that goal, but that it never could. As Zach Kotzer writes for Kill Screen, “drifting is not an absolute; it is a means to an end.” Absolute Drift needs its leaderboards and its car stunts because drifting in isolation just isn’t that interesting. Just as Tsuchiya incorporated drifting into his racing to spice up his corners, racing games have utilized drifting for the similar purpose of making themselves more interesting to play and watch.When you strip everything but drifting away from these games, sliding through corners begins to dull rather than excite. Absolute Drift may see drifting as an elevated form of racing, but there is a reason the sport has only ever garnered a niche audience. There are only so many ways you can drift the same turn before it starts to feel routine. This is a problem for games with far more robust handling systems than Absolute Drift can manage (your toy car feels like a boat cruising through a bowl of ice cream), which only exacerbates the problem as what is drifting but the precise understanding and control of a car’s grip and power.Absolute Drift’s devotion to a singular idea is compelling in its focus and clean production. Its sparse world is as easy on the eyes as the trance soundtrack is on the ears, and there is some fun to be had navigating these large sandboxes populated with fighter jets and Ferris Wheels. But that fun is akin to setting up a ramp and watching a Hot Wheels car fly down it, popping off the ground and begging you to do it again. Eventually you grow tired of this simple task and long for something more involving. But your toy is still just a Hot Wheels car, and this is still just a drifting game.You can find more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

number of helpful: 7 of 19 people (37%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												Absolute Drift has that borderline feeling between trying to be arcade and trying to be sim, and doing neither well. The camera angle says arcade, the fine control of steering says sim, the overall physics say they don't know what they are - and I don't know either.With the minimalist single-angle isometric style, they should have gone towards a challenging arcade experience, instead I got a frustrating blend of sim/arcade controls that is derived from what feels like a lightly modified UnityCar 2.0 asset package, which uses Pacejka curves and isn't great for drifting without code voodoo.The game still has potential to be fun, perhaps alternate camera angles providing a better perspective of what is going on would bring out the game's arcade/sim mixture better and make the controls more enjoyable. As it stands, it's a decent DnB playlist with a car game on top.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												Feels more like a tech demo than an actual game. No real story. You just drive around these open areas doing little objectives. There's basically only 4 objectives. That is making a jump, drifting between things, and drifting around something till you get 100%, and picking up collectibles. That's basically the whole game. There are tracks you can do, but you're just goign around drifting for points. The drifting is ok, but its very finnicky and oversensitive, leading to tons of spinning out. Having played many racing games requiring drifting, this isn't quit as well tuned. Sometimes you get everything right and it can be fun, but its mostly boring and repetitive. It's not inherently terrible, there's just not much to the game. Theres about 2-3 hours of playtime, which is a ripoff for the price, although I wouldn't want longer because of how you do the same thing from the first 10 min to the 3rd hour. 5.5/10.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												As someone who absolutely adores the likes of Drifting royalty (In cars I mean) such as the Nissan skyline R33 & R34, Toyaota supra, Nissan silvia S15 and any of the other RWD monster, I can honestly say that the idea behind this game is quite entertaining...So yeah, I think it's Ok, but it can certainly be improved. I like that there some old school cars (what looks to be a Toyota AE86?). It's quite a steep learning curve, and it does take a little bit to get use to, but after the tutorials and exploring all the worlds, you sorta get a feel for it. I like that you get to control some of the car settings, but in all honestly, they don't really feel as though they make a difference. But that's about as far as I'll go.. I'll get on with the bad points first;BAD POINTS:- It feels like driving on ice. Not particularly Realistic. - There's not enough cars/designs- The music is repetitive, similar (but still nice)- What's with the Minimalist design?- It's too short a game (i.e. unlocking all the worlds)Good Points:- There's quite a few things to do (with the different modes and free roam)- It's simple, yet satisfying- It kinda remids me of "Kill the bad guy"- What few cars there are, they all feel different to drift - You can select AUTO or Manual if you are a real car nerd!Overall, not a bad game. But I certainly wouldn't pay full price (Yep, I used♥♥♥♥♥ and rightly so). I'd probably just keep your 9 quid and save up for the likes of Dirt Rally if you wanna do epic Skids. But that is just my opinion4/10

Posted: February 7, 2016
												Firstly, I love this game because you can drive all over Europe. You have to manage your money, and make sure that, when you get out a loan from the bank, you have enough money to pay it back, or are at least making enough daily profit to pay it back.You also manage a business. You can hire drivers to work for you, and they will complete jobs for you, but you have to pay them a wage, plus some for every journey they complete. You level up they skills, that make them be better at certian things, like you can make them earn more money for going over a set distance, or you can make them carry high value or fragile cargo. They can also carry ADR materials, so things that could be dangourous. But you get paid more for that.You can always do 'Quick Jobs', and these are when the employer provides the truck, and you just go where they tell you. This is fun, but it starts to get boring, only doing short deliverys, so you can buy a truck, so that you can go further distances, and get more money.To conclude, I feel that anybody who likes games like Farm Simulator, or any simulator game should give this game a try, because it is a great way to unwind after a long day, and I have found it to be so much fun and very calming. Some people say that this is a boring game, I happen to disagree.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2016
												The tutorial didn't teach me how to play. It doesn't even guide you on what kind of rhythm/speed is best to make good drifts. The loading screen keeps telling me, "You're spinning out a lot. It's not about speed." There isn't even an on-screen indicator of speed, it's a topdown view, and your max speed is already glacial. It's hard to even gauge my speed! Considering this game's so minimal and the developers didn't feel the need to properly teach me the game, I'm not going to play further.This has the least immediately fun driving I've played, and I've played Pac-Man World Rally. It's like driving through syrup. Feels dreadful.I also have an almost ideological opposition to this game. The fun of drifting isn't in being in loose, weightless control... it's about being in loose, weightless control as a means to more quickly make sharp turns and return to top speed ASAP. It's a rhythmic thing.Glad I got this in a Humble Bundle with a game I actually wanted.

Posted: July 30, 2015
												This is a really cool game for racing fans, especially those that either, A: feel let down with the lack of drift events in newer games such as GRID Autosport, or B: just like going for high scores on leaderboards. Great presentation and audio mean that it's a pleasure to sit there for an hour or two, plugging away at the High Score on the Driftkhana boards. Take it from me, at the time of the review, I'm ranked anywhere from 2nd to 6th on all of them.The cars handle nicely, and feel like they have a lot of weight to them. The drifting requires you to think ahead about where you want to end up, and requires minute adjustments as you fly around a corner in order to not crash. It requires a little bit of practice, and top down view can occasionally be disorienting, but overall the game controls well and it feels good. It feels good to slide around a corner at high speed, and consistently nail drifts in order to build up a multiplier and score high points. The games core mechanics are incredibly solid.The Mirror's Edge style visuals are also a nice touch, and give a lot of flair and personality to the game. The music makes for good background noise, and there are a couple of pretty good tracks that I actually find myself enjoying a lot.Really, my only complaint is the lack of custom maps. This sort of leaderboard-focused game seems designed to come with a map editor.

												Fantastic little game. I had been following this for a couple months leading up to release anxiously awaiting. And it has not disappointed. First off; the drift physics are exactly what you'd want. Throttle is pressure sensitive, allowing you to be very precise with how hard/soft you push the car in a drift. Car sounds are crisp and vary from car-to-car. Handbrake is applied JUST right; some arcade driving games have handbrake engage WAY too strong and sling shot you around. I really dug the Mirror's Edge-like minimalist graphics theme, with red colored items being important against a white backdrop. The game is a bit short w/ 5 "worlds" each with 20 or so challenges to complete that don't take long at all to run through. I am hoping this will maybe receive Workshop support to add things like custom car skins & Events for extended replayability.All in all, for ~$10 I highly recommend if you are a fan of drift car culture at all.

Posted: December 6, 2015
												I enjoy Absolute Drift. That's really the bottom line of this review. I enjoy it, but I wish it were longer. The game is, at its core, a top-down arcade-style drift game that reminds me of the Gymkhana bits in DIRT 3. Only this time, there's no "Go share it on YouTube!" Absolute Drift is a game that leaves you alone with your car, some blank-faced obstacles, some quiet drum and bass tracks, and tire tracks that follow you into the sky.-----Gameplay: It's a small, relaxing game that's more about you enjoying the driving mechanic than completing any objectives. I beat the game in about 2 hours, but beating the game is really just unlocking all areas to drive around aimlessly. With the recent addition of a sort of difficulty switch, you can make your car handle in a way that's either more challenging or forgiving, but either way it's tremendous fun. 9/10Graphics/Visual Experience: This game is relaxing and the visuals are a big part of that. Being a simple top-down drifting game, there's very little pretending that any of the buildings or bridges are important as anything more than obstacles. Buildings and the ground are left the standard off-white color, while little details elsewhere are given a flourish to bring them a little more life (usually a shade of red). You have the option of 5 cars, each with their own ~5 colors and ~5 decals. The skidmarks follow you into the sky, which at first may seem like a silly detail but I felt it really added something to the game. 9/10Sound: Previously, the sound of squealing tires was a tad too loud but it's been cranked down as of late, meaning the relaxing atmosphere the music creates is far more effective. My only complaint with it is one that's my own fault, which is that despite liking drum and bass music, I tire of it very quickly and it all starts sounding the same. I need to try it while playing with my own music, but I haven't tried that yet. 8/10Replayability: It's one of those games that you have to be "in the mood" to play. While it's a fun game, the simplicity of the environment would work more as a strength should the world increase in size a little. In its current iteration, the world feels a little bare. However, should you find yourself liking the world, the gameplay will remain the same every time, and as I said before, "beating the game" isn't depriving you of any options or elements but merely recognition that you've unlocked all the parts of the open world. 7/10How it Runs: The game is simple and is about as demanding as you would think. There's not much that's going to tax your computer should you decide to purchase this game.

Posted: August 16, 2015
												Soo this game.... were do i start?If you love drifting, turbo whistles and hooing then this is the game for you.Word of caution though here are a few things i need to mention -NO WHEEL SUPPORT (ps4 and xbox controllers only)-Pretty much unplayble on keyboard -really simple graphics-Top down view only-You either will love the music or hate it (its a mics of Dubstep/Trap/EDM)-JDM only cars-The whole 'map" is divided into different zones that are locked at first and are unlocked through challeges (note that  untli now i have not experienced any loading screens between these zones since you drive to them) -THIS GAME IS CHALLENGING AND NOT SIMPLE AND YOU NEED TO HAVE SOME LEVEL OF DRIFITING ABILITY IN ORDER TO GET THE MOST FUN OUT OF IT.Despite this i love this game its just simple unadulterated drifting and hooing in zones full of tracks and challenges to do.  The game has a nice art style were the map and track are white with a few brightly colored buildings to mix things up and your car is the paintbrush. The game is nicely optimized and I can definitly see someone playing this on an unplugged laptop (Provided you have and controller). The game is just soo fun i can't stress this enough. The game is easy too get into but hard to masterand you willl spend hours trying to get to the top of the leaderboard.  The physics of this game are awesome and you cant just go full throttle into a bend and expect not to spin out this isnt need for speed but this just emphasizes the fact the this game needs wheel support i think i would be much nicer if it did. The game also has a sense of humor in the way it presents itself and its tutorials and the names of the cars, and since it doesnt take itself too seriously and you can just fun with it. So if like turbo whistle and slithering around a bend like your in Tokyo drift this is the game for you.

Posted: August 15, 2015
So let's talk about Absolute Drift:But before I'll gently slide through the curve let me give you a short overview about what you should consider if you want to buy this game:Do you love grinding a level for (even) hours just to get a good score?Do you love drifting?Do you drink too much sake?Do you love Drum & Bass / EDM?Do you love the roar of a motor and burnt rubber on the streets?Do you want to drive a mad drifting machine?If any of this can be applied to you then you should really consider buying it and maybe watch a video about it if the teaser and gameplay isn't enough for you.If you can relate to more than one point: BUY THIS GAME. YOU WON'T BE DISAPPOINTED.The game plays very smoothly and despite some complains about the keyboard controls in the reviews I find it to be ok. It plays similar to some other games concerning the "Racing"-genre.The minimalistic design paired with the soundtrack, a mix between soothing Drum & Bass and tender EDM, gives you a phenomenal game experience. You'll notice that you leave a trail of rubber behind you but the best thing is: It doesn't even stop when you're in the air! Someone mentioned that in one of the reviews but I think that this is such a great thing! If you start turning mid-air you'll see how and it just looks so very very pretty as well!The game's learning curve is pretty much just rising. You'll learn new maneuvers as you progress in the game and for sure ones you did not get teached by the game itself. The missions in the Free-Roam mode are (somewhat) forgiving which is great for beginners and no bad thing at all!Each of your vehicles has an own sound for the motor as well which is a minor thing but still worth mentioning.Oh - the events!They are SO much fun! If there is a track you really like you will even catch youself spending 10 minutes if not even 1 hour or more trying to perfect your score and getting your global rank up on that specific track. The music also helps when you are grinding in one of the levels and if you want to stop you can just do that and mess around in the Free-Roam mode.The Free-Roam mode let's you do whatever you want with your drift machine. [spolier]You can jump over ramps, destroy blocks, donut around helicopters or just speed up a mountain track. Or you can just drive up a ramp and fly straight into the water to hear that cute splashing sound! [/spoiler]I don't know if I forgot anything about the game and I hope that the devs will add more events or even new worlds or cars to the game. I'm really excited for what is going to come.If I had to rate it on a scale of 10 I'd give it 10/10 *insert funny joke about the game encouraging drunk driving here*

Posted: June 7, 2016
												Great art direction - minimalistic, soft colors, and sharp edges combine into a pleasing visual experience. Tire tracks show your course and how to replicate it (or not). A calming soundtrack is paired with the screaming of your car's engine, which can get a little annoying, but is also consistent enough to drown out with the music.Gameplay is centered around point-based driving, drifting around corners as close as you can, as fast as you can, and as sideways as you can. The gameplay is enticing and draws in perfectionists; I had a lot of good fun honing my times!I've played this on my friend's account with a Xbox 360 controller and enjoyed it for hours. I got this part of the latest Humble Bundle and tried it out with my Xbox One Elite controller. The support for said controller, as well as the Xbox One controller and the Wireless Dongle, is broken. No matter what I do the controller pulls to the left constantly.The fixes for the XONE controller are hit and miss - works for some, doesn't work for others, but they are just workarounds. A game like this needs inherent support for controllers. My DS4 controller did not work either.I'm hesitant to recommend Absolute Drift. I had a lot of fun before I switched to the current generation of controllers. I would avoid this game if you use the current controllers; if you use a 360 controller or use KB/M (I would recommend not to), then you should be fine.EDIT: The developer supplied a beta version of the newest build of the game and it solved my control issues. Now Absolute Drift, once the beta version is pushed to live, is a game worth recommending.

Posted: June 17, 2016
												Fun little game that's captivating for short bursts of time. I would get it on sale as I don't think it's worth it at it's normal price, but if you're really into top down driving games I would go for it. Just a heads up, make sure you change the transmission settings to manual. The game has automatic set to default for some reason and it's almost impossible to control your car around corners or get the neccessary torque to start a drift without using the handbrake with auto.

Posted: June 16, 2016
												This is a racer where times don't matter - sliding cars around corners for points is the core mechanic.If you've ever played a top down or isometric racer before, this one has a great driving model. I've played using a logitech gamepad F510 and the car handles well, giving a sense of balance and yet still requiring care to avoid losing the back end and spinning out. All the cars feel like rear-wheel drive models,  so braking into the corner and burning rubber will float you round the corner. Burn too hard and spin out. Burn not enough and you'll lose your precious multipliers. Finding the balance is key.The roaming mode introduces you to the various driving challenges - loops, point-to-point and gymkhana events (where you drive as many tricks for points in 2 minutes). There is enough variety to keep the interest up - I completed the game in about five hours, so its not huge. However, I still have the urge to improve my scores - there are worldwide leaderboards to compare yourself against. Also the leaderboards show which car was used for the score - its not always the more powerful cars at the top...Recommended if you like driving games.

Quite alike but for a game like this, different enough.Cons: Too few achievements: you need something more to draw you back day after day. Countdown before the race starts. Great idea, but it's very fast paced game and you end up restarting the race quite a few times when you're trying to beat your friends score. Three seconds is a long wait, too long. Should be: click restart, BOOM! GO! Also you should be able to change car without having to quit the race.Other than that, I enjoyed this very much, thank you!

												This game features 3 level types: A-to-B mountain tracks, freestyle drift courses, and 3-lap race tracks. The free roam map has additional missions you can perform only once, such as donut around a light pole, drift between buildings, jump over a river, etc.I was pretty terrible with the drift controls for most of the game, but finally seemed to start figuring it out near the end. (The controls work just fine; I am just not very good at drifting.) Despite repeatedly crashing into walls, I really enjoyed playing this game. I enjoyed the game even more once I finally figured out how to drive and drift. I particularly loved driving around the map in free roam and discovering new missions to complete. The minimalistic art style and varied environments provides for a beautiful game that keeps you coming back for more.Pros+ Beautiful minimalistic art style+ Many missions to complete+ Large soundtrack with ability to skip tracks whenever you want+ Ramps! Launch your car into the air and spin out of control+ Customizable car body and paint jobs+ Controller supportCons- Not much replayability once you've completed all free-roam missions- Difficult learning curve for controls- Only three types of levels gives feeling of repeating the same thing over and overThe game trailer video perfectly shows a taste of what you'll experience playing this game. If the video makes you even remotely interested, then buy it!

Posted: July 5, 2016
												I genuinely wish I could give a neutral review for this one. The game is not bad. In fact, it is very good at what it does.Absolute Drift is a minimalist drifting game, in which you're a white (can change) car, in a white world, with white objects everywhere. Except for a few things. Orange colored objects are destroyable and/or important. Each "world" also seems to have another flavor color splashed in periodically. (i.e. Yellow in world 2, Blue in world 3, etc.) And each "world" you unlock by completing various "missions" (such as doing donuts, spins, drifting between obstacles, etc.). There are no time limits as far as I can tell, and it's just a very open-world (on a table top), relaxed, easy going drifting game with no rules, no conflict, and no consequences.All of that, it does EXTREMELY well. However, it is not FUN. At least not to me. I'm playing on an XBox controller, and I also tried it out on my keyboard. There's five controls. Gas/Accelerate, Brake/Reverse, Steering, and E-Brake. You can also remove automatic transmission and have another shift up/down pair of buttons available. But I found the shifting on this tedious, and without shifting the game is repetitive. You can learn to do all you can do within the first ten seconds of playing. Spinning only works in reverse as far as I can tell, and "donuts" are just, basically, a slow lazy drift. When you are told to donut something, you can get 10%, crash, and get 10% more, crash, and repeat until complete. I've played plenty of other racing games with drifting components, and a few other drifting-centered games. This one, you have significantly less control over your vehicle. And the way the game calculates a "drift" you can literally drive straight up to your obstacle and slam on your brakes and succeed in just about any of the "missions". There is no incentive I can tell to do well (other than placing higher in the global rankings), and no punishments if you just crash into a wall over and over until you succeed.To feel successful, one must suceed. To succeed, there must be a chance of failure. To avoid failure, one must learn. Learning is caused by either positive or negative reinforcement, or some combination. This game has none. Perhaps I just suck at this game, but I didn't find it fun.TL;DR: If you want a laid-back drifting game with no clear rules, where you can just drive around a pristine environment to your hearts content, this is for you. Otherwise, look elsewhere.#TOFU #JDM #HOONEDIT: It doesn't seem to be recording my time correctly. Anyone who's played it knows it takes longer than "0.1 hours" to get that far.

I highly reccomend this.

Posted: August 14, 2015
												Absolute Drift... Let's see; its like Micro Machines meets Mirrors Edge with a soundtrack that takes me back to the early Test Drive and NFS days. Dead simple to pick up and play, but incredibly challenging to master..The areas in free-roam are large and diverse, flowing seamlessly from industrial districts to twisty mountain passes, which keeps things interesting throughout the map. Each car also has very different handling characteristics, which makes it possible for each person to find their perfect car for different events.Visually the game is crisp and clean, dare I say almost elegant in it's minimalistic nature. Because 95% of it is white, it is tricky to see where the track is going uphill or downhill, but even that becomes a moot point once you get used to it.The way each vehicle slides is surprisingly realistic, with all the usual drift ideas working as you could expect in first-person driving simulators; slamming anchors in the middle of a slide will allow the car to drift out wider, flooring the accelerator with a high angle drift will spin you out more often than not, even the steering feels like the vehicle weight actually transfers fore and aft, allowing for some pretty spectacular moves while flicking the car around tight bends...All in all, this game is put together incredibly well. I do so hope we get some extra content for this in the future, I've run out of road and now I need more! (:

Posted: October 4, 2016
												All achievements unlocked, I can finally write a review.I have never thought a game about drifting would be interested, I am not a fan of racing games at all. Absolute Drift was a random choice from my library and I absolutely loved it.In the game you have to do some drifting tasks by driving a car. Sounds simple, but mastering the car takes hours.Performing the tasks seems to be easy at the beginning. But with increasing difficulty, it becomes bloody difficult in the end. Honestly speaking, getting the last achievement 'Complete all event challenges in the game.' is a masochistic task.Still, despite of repeating some stages again and again (in some cases for few hours) the game is not boring at all. There was a little irritation, of course, but somehow the failures were motivational to keep playing.Absolute Drift has a minimalistic graphic. Tracks are plain white with some red addons. The driving car looks like a toy among a white bricls jungle. But this game does not need anything more - instead of distracting colours and complicated environment it gives an opportunity to focus on tasks.Another thing is the soundtrack. It suits perfectly. Actually, despite of my dislike of the music genre used in the game, I enjoyed the songs which brings a proper ambience.After all those hours spent with Absolute Drift I can recommend it to everyone.

Posted: December 22, 2015
												Lots of fun for not lots of money. Psudeo-isometric drifting game that is accessible to the beginner yet offers something for even the most experienced sim racer. This game forgoes the usual lisenced cars, awful bodykits and whiny community trying to organize endurance races for a more simple, beautific approach. A simple set of enviroments, with just enough car choices to make you feel like you have some options, is peppered with obstacles and objectives for you to slide your way around. The only shame is that there isn't more of everything - the few car choices are varied, the enviroments are different, and the original music is great background. If you grind and try to do everything, the whole "campaign" and all the achievements will still only take an experienced player ~5 hours or less. A more casual play gets maybe 10 before finishing the campaign and maybe another 3 for the remaining achievements. Also, there's a reason they recommend a controller - it will make your life better. If you want the challenge or more gametime, you can try the keys, but if I were you I'd grab your handy dandy 360 pad you have sitting around.Pros:-Pick up and play-Nice soundtrack-Pretty to look at -You can drift a van, which is pretty sweetCons:-Easy to learn, hard to master, especially if you don't play a lot of driving games. -Short. Like, sit down and play it straight through by accident short.-Limited replayability.

Posted: December 24, 2015
												A fun little game with a GREAT soundtrack and a cool minimalist style.The free-roam mode (the "story"-like mode) is about 90 minutes of play depending on how much you suck. Could probably be speedrun much faster. There's a bunch of drift and driftkhana tracks each with their own leaderboards, so the competitive leaderboard types of players will probably get much more than 90 minutes out of this game. The drift mechanics seem mildly accurate, for a really low-grip world.Unfortunately the goal detection is kinda dodgy. Where you have to do donuts around an object, you actually just have to be drifting a certain angle, not even in the correct direction, within some radius of the object. You'll accidentally half-complete some objectives driving past it. Drifts to complete objectives don't have to be successful, you can slide past, tick off an objective, and then slam into the wall (the exception to this is that actually hitting clipping points doesn't give points, and donking donut objects sometimes resets them). The result of all this is that you can basically fumble your way through the whole game (you do gotta git gud for the leaderboard modes though).Also there's a difficulty setting that seems to do nothing. I don't even know.All up - it's a fun little toy, but it's not really a complete product.

Posted: December 6, 2015
												I enjoy Absolute Drift. That's really the bottom line of this review. I enjoy it, but I wish it were longer. The game is, at its core, a top-down arcade-style drift game that reminds me of the Gymkhana bits in DIRT 3. Only this time, there's no "Go share it on YouTube!" Absolute Drift is a game that leaves you alone with your car, some blank-faced obstacles, some quiet drum and bass tracks, and tire tracks that follow you into the sky.-----Gameplay: It's a small, relaxing game that's more about you enjoying the driving mechanic than completing any objectives. I beat the game in about 2 hours, but beating the game is really just unlocking all areas to drive around aimlessly. With the recent addition of a sort of difficulty switch, you can make your car handle in a way that's either more challenging or forgiving, but either way it's tremendous fun. 9/10Graphics/Visual Experience: This game is relaxing and the visuals are a big part of that. Being a simple top-down drifting game, there's very little pretending that any of the buildings or bridges are important as anything more than obstacles. Buildings and the ground are left the standard off-white color, while little details elsewhere are given a flourish to bring them a little more life (usually a shade of red). You have the option of 5 cars, each with their own ~5 colors and ~5 decals. The skidmarks follow you into the sky, which at first may seem like a silly detail but I felt it really added something to the game. 9/10Sound: Previously, the sound of squealing tires was a tad too loud but it's been cranked down as of late, meaning the relaxing atmosphere the music creates is far more effective. My only complaint with it is one that's my own fault, which is that despite liking drum and bass music, I tire of it very quickly and it all starts sounding the same. I need to try it while playing with my own music, but I haven't tried that yet. 8/10Replayability: It's one of those games that you have to be "in the mood" to play. While it's a fun game, the simplicity of the environment would work more as a strength should the world increase in size a little. In its current iteration, the world feels a little bare. However, should you find yourself liking the world, the gameplay will remain the same every time, and as I said before, "beating the game" isn't depriving you of any options or elements but merely recognition that you've unlocked all the parts of the open world. 7/10How it Runs: The game is simple and is about as demanding as you would think. There's not much that's going to tax your computer should you decide to purchase this game.

Posted: June 19, 2016
												Absolute Drift is a lot of fun.  Once you get a hang of the controls, you'll be drifting along effortlessly and feel just a little bit like Fujiwara Takumi.The game has 3 modes: Drift Track, Driftkhana, Mountain.  Each presented in a clean, minimal look and feel, which in my mind, enhances your experience since there's no distraction from what this game is about: Drifting.Drift track is simply what is says: a track to drift around.Driftkhana can be said to be a timed playground with boxes to knock over, demarcated areas to spin in, make doughnuts and just in general do as many drift tricks as you can in the set amount of time.Mountain is similar to Drift track, only the "track" mimics a mountain downhill where you traverse it from end to finish.The aim in each of the modes: score the as many points as possible.At first this is quite difficult as you get to grips with the car and the handling.  But the controls are forgiving, as are the physics.  Soon you'll learn the limits of the car and the ins and outs of the handling and physics together, throwing the car around like second nature.Furthermore, connecting all of the events, are hub areas (5 in total), each containing between 18 and 25 missions to complete.  Complete all missions in an area to unlock the next.You can also access all of the events from the main menu and jump straight in if you like ( no need to unlock them first ).Absolute drift is great for simply relaxing and pouring out any stress you have into the satisfying act of watching a micro-machine sized car, drift around corners, boxes, containers and trains.Highly recommended.NOTE: Absolute drift is purely a singleplayer experience.  Don't approach if you this is a drift racing game.

Posted: June 18, 2016
												Overall awesome short game.Everyone that is into drifting should get this game!The minimalistic looks combined with impulsive soundtrack invite you to drift in the small open world.You unlock the different stages of the game by completing challenges like drifting between certain buildings or doing donuts around trees.I'm having a tremendous amount of fun only by doing that and trying to obtain the perfect flow and seeing the smooth lines the tires leave behind. Topping your Highscore in one of the Driftkhanas resemble those in Dirt 3 and ain't any inferior.Each of the 6 differnt cars distinguishes from the others in terms of maneuverability and torque so you can pick the one that suits your skill best. No matter what car you pick you will still have a hard time knowing the point when you have to countersteer or back down on the throttle.But achieving the perfect combination of drifts will reward you with an emotion, that is just as plain and straightforward as the game itself. . . PURE JOY!The content is slim and you can easily finish the game in under one hour.Mastering the arts of drifting will take you much longer and i can only speak of myself but this game was more fun than almost every racing game i played in the last year.

Posted: June 7, 2016
												Great art direction - minimalistic, soft colors, and sharp edges combine into a pleasing visual experience. Tire tracks show your course and how to replicate it (or not). A calming soundtrack is paired with the screaming of your car's engine, which can get a little annoying, but is also consistent enough to drown out with the music.Gameplay is centered around point-based driving, drifting around corners as close as you can, as fast as you can, and as sideways as you can. The gameplay is enticing and draws in perfectionists; I had a lot of good fun honing my times!I've played this on my friend's account with a Xbox 360 controller and enjoyed it for hours. I got this part of the latest Humble Bundle and tried it out with my Xbox One Elite controller. The support for said controller, as well as the Xbox One controller and the Wireless Dongle, is broken. No matter what I do the controller pulls to the left constantly.The fixes for the XONE controller are hit and miss - works for some, doesn't work for others, but they are just workarounds. A game like this needs inherent support for controllers. My DS4 controller did not work either.I'm hesitant to recommend Absolute Drift. I had a lot of fun before I switched to the current generation of controllers. I would avoid this game if you use the current controllers; if you use a 360 controller or use KB/M (I would recommend not to), then you should be fine.EDIT: The developer supplied a beta version of the newest build of the game and it solved my control issues. Now Absolute Drift, once the beta version is pushed to live, is a game worth recommending.

												Fun little game that's captivating for short bursts of time. Posted: June 16, 2016
												This is a racer where times don't matter - sliding cars around corners for points is the core mechanic.If you've ever played a top down or isometric racer before, this one has a great driving model. I've played using a logitech gamepad F510 and the car handles well, giving a sense of balance and yet still requiring care to avoid losing the back end and spinning out. All the cars feel like rear-wheel drive models,  so braking into the corner and burning rubber will float you round the corner. Burn too hard and spin out. Burn not enough and you'll lose your precious multipliers. Finding the balance is key.The roaming mode introduces you to the various driving challenges - loops, point-to-point and gymkhana events (where you drive as many tricks for points in 2 minutes). There is enough variety to keep the interest up - I completed the game in about five hours, so its not huge. However, I still have the urge to improve my scores - there are worldwide leaderboards to compare yourself against. Also the leaderboards show which car was used for the score - its not always the more powerful cars at the top...Recommended if you like driving games.

Posted: August 10, 2015
												So far I've only spent about 20 minutes playing the game. I haven't tried it with a keyboard/mouse yet because of some warnings I've come across, so I cannot personally recommend a controller over a keyboard and mouse. I love the concept, infact, I love the game! The missions in Free Play are fun to do and fun to look for. The drift tracks and tutorials are setup very nicely. Even the games soundtrack is nice, some chill electro EDM music. All around the game is great.However... I can't seem to grasp the drifting mechanic. One moment I'm understeering, the next I'm spinning out of control with nothing but a wall to stop me. I'm glad crashing in this game doesn't result in failure, otherwise I would've stopped within 20 minutes. I feel like this game isn't something I'll be hooked on forever though, sadly. This is only due to the fact that I'm much more interested in other genres. Anyways, don't buy this game looking for easy drifting is all I'm saying. It's challenging, yet fun!EDIT: I've gotten about 80 minutes into the game and I've made it to the beginning of World 5. The game has a great variety of cars and customization. More than you would think it would have! I am getting the hang of the drifting and other tricks and it is now a much easier game; and it got more fun than before. Understanding the mechanics is quite strange... it's like I'm understeering and oversteering at the same time. If you're trying to go for a long drift, don't go too hard on the gas, you will spin out very quickly. Always use the handbrake unless you're going to fast to a wall, then you should hard brake.Anyways; this was the greatest $11 I've ever spent!EDIT: I've got around 140 minutes into the game and I finished it. Not much replayability in my opinion. Just the same tracks and free roam courses you played in the story mode, which is quite dull if you ask me. I'm not saying I expect a huge story, but 2 hours of content? Really? Still an awfully fun game and I spend more money on things that last for 10 minutes, so I'm not complaining.

Posted: September 5, 2015
												This isn't really much of a game, it's more of an exercise for drifting in bigger racing games. That being said, drifting in this game is extremely hard, as you spin out of control very easily. Although this may lower your hopes, when you have sort of conquered the ability to drift in this game, it's really fun. The race courses are all there, with time trial mechanics. There are also courses where you have to get points in a certain amount of time by drifting, spinning donuts, etcetera. Next to that, there's a free roam mode where you can explore quite a big world, all minimalistic and good-looking with quests to advance to the next area of said world (FYI, it's one big world. no loading screens whatsoever). Now, I would recommend this game, but there are two problems I have with it: the quests you have to do to advance to the next part of the world are extremely repetitive, and there aren't that many race/trick courses. For its price being 11,99, this really isn't much of a game. I WOULD recommend it if it's either on sale or cheap to get through retail. But yeah, for its price, the game is really short. I completed the free roaming mode in around 1,5 hours, and, like I said, there aren't that many other things to do next to break your previous record on racing or trick courses.TL;DR: Too expensive, recommended if cheaper.

Posted: December 24, 2015
												A fun little game with a GREAT soundtrack and a cool minimalist style.The free-roam mode (the "story"-like mode) is about 90 minutes of play depending on how much you suck. Could probably be speedrun much faster. There's a bunch of drift and driftkhana tracks each with their own leaderboards, so the competitive leaderboard types of players will probably get much more than 90 minutes out of this game. The drift mechanics seem mildly accurate, for a really low-grip world.Unfortunately the goal detection is kinda dodgy. Where you have to do donuts around an object, you actually just have to be drifting a certain angle, not even in the correct direction, within some radius of the object. You'll accidentally half-complete some objectives driving past it. Drifts to complete objectives don't have to be successful, you can slide past, tick off an objective, and then slam into the wall (the exception to this is that actually hitting clipping points doesn't give points, and donking donut objects sometimes resets them). The result of all this is that you can basically fumble your way through the whole game (you do gotta git gud for the leaderboard modes though).Also there's a difficulty setting that seems to do nothing. I don't even know.All up - it's a fun little toy, but it's not really a complete product.

Posted: December 6, 2015
												I enjoy Absolute Drift. That's really the bottom line of this review. I enjoy it, but I wish it were longer. The game is, at its core, a top-down arcade-style drift game that reminds me of the Gymkhana bits in DIRT 3. Only this time, there's no "Go share it on YouTube!" Absolute Drift is a game that leaves you alone with your car, some blank-faced obstacles, some quiet drum and bass tracks, and tire tracks that follow you into the sky.-----Gameplay: It's a small, relaxing game that's more about you enjoying the driving mechanic than completing any objectives. I beat the game in about 2 hours, but beating the game is really just unlocking all areas to drive around aimlessly. With the recent addition of a sort of difficulty switch, you can make your car handle in a way that's either more challenging or forgiving, but either way it's tremendous fun. 9/10Graphics/Visual Experience: This game is relaxing and the visuals are a big part of that. Being a simple top-down drifting game, there's very little pretending that any of the buildings or bridges are important as anything more than obstacles. Buildings and the ground are left the standard off-white color, while little details elsewhere are given a flourish to bring them a little more life (usually a shade of red). You have the option of 5 cars, each with their own ~5 colors and ~5 decals. The skidmarks follow you into the sky, which at first may seem like a silly detail but I felt it really added something to the game. 9/10Sound: Previously, the sound of squealing tires was a tad too loud but it's been cranked down as of late, meaning the relaxing atmosphere the music creates is far more effective. My only complaint with it is one that's my own fault, which is that despite liking drum and bass music, I tire of it very quickly and it all starts sounding the same. I need to try it while playing with my own music, but I haven't tried that yet. 8/10Replayability: It's one of those games that you have to be "in the mood" to play. While it's a fun game, the simplicity of the environment would work more as a strength should the world increase in size a little. In its current iteration, the world feels a little bare. However, should you find yourself liking the world, the gameplay will remain the same every time, and as I said before, "beating the game" isn't depriving you of any options or elements but merely recognition that you've unlocked all the parts of the open world. 7/10How it Runs: The game is simple and is about as demanding as you would think. There's not much that's going to tax your computer should you decide to purchase this game.

Posted: December 22, 2015
												Lots of fun for not lots of money. Psudeo-isometric drifting game that is accessible to the beginner yet offers something for even the most experienced sim racer. This game forgoes the usual lisenced cars, awful bodykits and whiny community trying to organize endurance races for a more simple, beautific approach. A simple set of enviroments, with just enough car choices to make you feel like you have some options, is peppered with obstacles and objectives for you to slide your way around. The only shame is that there isn't more of everything - the few car choices are varied, the enviroments are different, and the original music is great background. If you grind and try to do everything, the whole "campaign" and all the achievements will still only take an experienced player ~5 hours or less. A more casual play gets maybe 10 before finishing the campaign and maybe another 3 for the remaining achievements. Also, there's a reason they recommend a controller - it will make your life better. If you want the challenge or more gametime, you can try the keys, but if I were you I'd grab your handy dandy 360 pad you have sitting around.Pros:-Pick up and play-Nice soundtrack-Pretty to look at -You can drift a van, which is pretty sweetCons:-Easy to learn, hard to master, especially if you don't play a lot of driving games. -Short. Like, sit down and play it straight through by accident short.-Limited replayability.
